urn:contentItem:55BC-JHD1-JD34-V2YM-00000-00An elegy for Green Island2002-02-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:50ZLexisNexisWEEKEND REVIEWPg. 4An elegy for Green IslandPaul Monk Paul Monk is senior fellow of the Australian Thinking Skills Institute and convenes a graduate seminar on security issues in contemporary Asia at Melbourne University.

Paul Monk on the future of human rights in the Chinese world

Green Island lies just off the south-east coast of Taiwan. For decades it was Taiwan's most notorious place of incarceration for political prisoners. Built during the so-called White Terror of the early 1950s, it held thousands of political prisoners at one time. There were 14,000 there in the mid-1950s, according to official figures.1 Thereafter, numbers declined, but the prison was not closed until after the end of martial law, in 1987. In that era, officially, 29,407 people were imprisoned for political reasons. Unofficially, Guomindang figures have put the total at up to 70,000. According to none other than Wang Sheng, a leading figure in the Guomindang repressive apparatus for many years, the number executed was about 15 per cent of the total, or between 4,500 and 10,000 people. The Ministry of Justice says the execution files have long since been burned.2

In the 1990s, a memorial was built on Green Island, to commemorate those imprisoned and executed in the harsh years before democratisation came to Taiwan. The memorial is simple and austere. Standing at its entrance, one can look out over the vastness of the Pacific Ocean and contrast its immense openness with the deadly confinement to which the memorial bears witness. Just past the entrance, descending into the court of the memorial, there is a long wall. On it are inscribed, in Chinese characters, the names of 750 prisoners whose records have been checked. Against the names of those executed there is a small mark. They are many.

Far from Green Island, in the heart of Taipei, there is another memorial to the victims of Guomindang repression: the 2/28 Peace Park and Museum. Here is commemorated the fearful bloodletting that occurred between February 28 and late March 1947, when the citizens of Taiwan rose up against misrule by mainlanders and were crushed in a brutal military operation by Chiang Kaishek's armed forces. For decades the history of these events was politically suppressed by the Guomindang, but the Taiwanese did not forget and the museum now records the general outline of what happened at that time.

For many mainlanders it is deeply upsetting to confront this history and there are some who still insist that it is not history, but Taiwanese nationalist propaganda. They are mistaken. There were many witnesses to the events at the time, not least among them the American diplomat, George Kerr, who set down accounts of what they saw.3 Taiwanese exiles kept the matter alive, claiming that 20,000 people had been massacred. In 1991, two Chinese and one American scholar published a detailed examination of the matter, in which they estimated that the number of deaths, almost all Taiwanese, at between 8,000 and 10,000.4 That was a conservative estimate. In 1995, the Guomindang itself apologised for the terrible excesses of 1947 and admitted that the number of Taiwanese killed in 1947 was between 18,000 and 28,000.5

These are numbing statistics. An equivalent level of bloodshed in Australia today would mean some 75,000 or more people being executed in a matter of weeks. Small wonder that even the pro-Guomindang Ramon Myers and his colleagues, in 1991, described the 1947 massacres as being followed by a "glooming peace" which "covered Taiwan like a blanket of ashes laid down by a forest fire".6 The Green Island memorial and the 2/28 Memorial Museum, however, make the dead more than statistics. They also rub away some of the numbness, by physically signifying that the truth has come out, that the cause has been vindicated and that repression as a means for resolving political differences has been repudiated. The "glooming peace" has been supplanted by a vigorous green growth without further violent upheaval and the heirs of those executed in 1947 have taken office as the legitimate government of Taiwan.

This is a human rights story which should be much more widely known and understood than it is. It is a paradigm case of democratisation, which merits emulation in a world still grievously beset by ruthless political violence. It is a shining example, within the Chinese world, of what is possible when traditional authoritarianism and ideological bloody-mindedness are replaced by magnanimity, imagination and principle. And it is, finally, a dramatic proof that human rights are not something confected by Western civilisation to interfere in the cultural and political domains of post-colonial states. They are fundamental and universal principles, without which barbarous violence and arbitrary rule will occur and go unchecked.

When Taiwan was handed back to the Chinese government in 1945, after the defeat of Japan in World War II, it was in excellent condition. The Japanese had been savage conquerors in China and elsewhere in Asia between 1937 and 1945, but in Taiwan, which they had taken from the Chinese empire in 1895, they had been immensely constructive colonial masters, developing rail and port infrastructure, industry and agriculture, education and public administration. Thousands of Taiwanese received good educations in Japan and played dignified roles in the life of the island under Japanese rule. In consequence, they found the contrast with Guomindang rule after 1945 a shock. This was especially so as they had hoped that the political philosophy of the Guomindang Sun Yat-sen's Three Principles of the People would entail sound and democratic government.

By 1946, educated Taiwanese had invented a wry pun to characterise Guomindang rule. The San Min Chu-I (Three Principles of the People), they quipped, had turned into Ts'an-min Chu-I (Cruel Personism).7 Nothing the Japanese had ever done in Taiwan prepared the Taiwanese for what happened, however, when they rebelled against their mainland rulers. The civil war between the Guomindang and the communists had just entered its final phase in February 1947 and the Guomindang acted ruthlessly to root out opposition on their southern flank in Taiwan. Thousands of regular troops were put ashore at Keelung and Kaohsiung. They fired indiscriminately, then proceeded to round up and slaughter hundreds of civic leaders and thousands of ordinary citizens.

Not least among the victims were countless idealistic young students. Kerr wrote, "We saw students tied together, being driven to the execution grounds, usually along the river banks and ditches about Taipei, or at the waterfront in Keelung. One foreigner counted more than thirty young bodies in student uniforms lying along the roadside east of Taipei; they had had their noses and ears slit or hacked off and many had been castrated. Two students were beheaded near my front gate. Bodies lay unclaimed on the roadside embankment near the Mission compound ... For days the dead continued to be washed up in Keelung Harbor ... The atrocities perpetrated at Kaohsiung were (if possible) even more revolting than the mass executions and torture used at Taipei". 8

The White Terror did not involve massacres on this scale. It lasted longer, but was more discriminating in its suppression of opposition to the Guomindang.9 It began in 1949, as Chiang Kaishek's Guomindang fled from defeat on the mainland and sought to both consolidate their hold on the island against the Taiwanese and to root out real or suspected Communist infiltrators in their chaotic ranks. It was in these years that the Green Island prisons were built and filled. It was a process wretchedly similar in character to what was happening on the mainland at the same time, as Mao Zedong's Communists purged the country of counter-revolutionaries, warlords, Guomindang officers and officials and feudal reactionaries. It can have been no consolation to the Taiwanese to have known, if indeed they did, that things were even worse on the mainland. And this remained the case throughout the 1950s and 1960s, while Chiang Kaishek was alive.

Of the thousands of cases of repression from that era, those of Lei Chen, Su Ting-chi and Peng Ming-min are almost paradigm cases of political persecution. Lei Chen was a leading liberal journalist who was arrested in 1961, along with three colleagues, for advocating clean and fair elections. He was sentenced to 10 years in prison for this heinous offence. When a young student, Su Ting-chi, organised a petition for clemency on his behalf, he was arrested, tortured, tried for sedition and executed, in May 1962. His wife was sentenced to life imprisonment for refusing to denounce him. Peng Ming-min, a brilliant young, Japanese-educated political scientist at National Taiwan University, was arrested in 1964 for appealing to all the people of Taiwan, both Taiwanese and mainlanders, to work together to establish a democratic state.10

He and two of his students were sentenced to prison terms of from eight to 10 years.

These case histories provide a sense of perspective. They invite searching comparisons with the persecution of democratic dissidents in China right up to the present. The dissent of Lei Chen and Peng Ming-min in the early 1960s directly anticipated the dissent of Liu Binyan, Fang Lizhi, Wei Jingsheng and many, many others in China one or two decades later.11 Lei, Su and Peng were not firebrands but individuals who

sought to make the Guomindang fulfil its charter to bring democracy, not dictatorship, to the Chinese world. It was in exactly this spirit that Wei Jingsheng, imprisoned by Deng Xiaoping for declaring that without democracy there is no modernisation, challenged the

Communist Party throughout the 1980s and 1990s.12

The core problem faced by all of these individuals, whether under the Guomindang or the communists, was the repressive nature of Chinese political culture, its inveterate lack of recognition of the dignity of the individual and the rights of the citizen. Bo Yang, a mainlander who fled communism in the 1940s and was jailed by the Guomindang on Taiwan in 1967 for "defaming the leadership", is now the director of the Human Rights Education Foundation in Taipei. In 1984, after his release from Green Island, he gave a speech at Iowa University which was later published under the title The Ugly Chinaman. His reflections in that speech still cannot be published openly in China, but have been through numerous reprints in democratic Taiwan.

"During my incarceration," he reflected, "I spent a lot of time contemplating my fate. What crimes had I committed? What laws had I broken? I continued pondering these questions after I was released and began to wonder whether mine was an abnormal or special case." Mainlanders he met in America, who had escaped Communist China, told him: "Someone like you would never have made it as far as the Red Guards or the Cultural Revolution. You'd have been lucky to survive the Anti-Rightist Movement." Given the antiquity and richness of Chinese civilisation, Bo Yang found this a dismal reality at the end of the 20th century. "Why," he asked, "must a Chinese person with the courage to speak an iota of truth suffer this sort of fate? I've asked a number of people from the mainland why they ended up in prison. The answer was invariably, `I spoke the truth.' ... But why does speaking the truth lead to such unfortunate consequences? My answer is that this is not a problem of any particular individual but rather of Chinese culture as a whole."13

We now know better. We know that the lack of human rights has a long history in China, but that it is neither peculiar to Chinese culture, nor ineradicable within Chinese culture. We also know that the change from abuse of human rights to systematic respect for them can be brought about constitutionally and peacefully from within a Chinese polity. We know that individual Chinese citizens, free of prompting by any external power and proceeding only on the basis of reason and experience and the few good examples on offer around the world, can both aspire to such rights and bring them into being.

We know this because it has happened on Taiwan. The big breakthrough has yet to come in mainland China, but the time has passed when any sort of cultural fatalism or ideological rationalisation can serve to excuse the abuses still practised by the Chinese Communist Party. The Guomindang, which it defeated in the violence stakes long ago, has shown it a clean pair of heels in the democratisation stakes since the death of Chiang Kaishek.

The breakthrough on Taiwan is, therefore, of world historical significance. No single aspect of it, however, is quite so remarkable as the fact that it was initiated by none other than Chiang Ching-kuo, the son of the old dictator and for many years one of the chief guardians of his dictatorship. In his pathbreaking biography of the younger Chiang, Jay Taylor has done an immense service to the cause of historical transformation in Chinese political culture. In it, Taylor tells a story that few people can have known through all the years when Chiang Ching-kuo ruled the Republic of China on Taiwan, whether as his father's regent between 1955 and 1975 or in his own right until his death in January 1988. It is a story of deep political learning under the most testing circumstances. It should be required reading in every Chinese home and for anyone trying to think through the modernisation and democratisation of Chinese political culture.

Chiang Ching-kuo was a contemporary of Deng Xiaoping and if Plutarch himself were to write a modern, global Parallel Lives, as he did of Greek and Roman statesmen long ago, then Taylor has shown that he would have to parallel these two lives. The two were classmates in Moscow in 1926, learning to be good communists. Chiang's girlfriend in Moscow was the daughter of the warlord Feng Yu-hsiang, for whom Deng went to work on his return to China. Deng organised the Anti-Rightist campaign for Mao Zedong in the 1950s, while Chiang Ching-kuo organised the White Terror and the Green Island "New Life Institute" for his father at the same time. Both saw the need for reform in the early 1970s, but could do little at that time.14 Deng imprisoned Wei Jingsheng in 1979-80, even as Chiang imprisoned Shih Ming-te and Annette Lu.15 But then the astounding break came: Deng recoiled from democratic liberalisation in the 1980s, while Chiang embraced it. Deng turned against his enlightened liberal heirs apparent, Hu Yaobang and Zhao Ziyang, while Chiang ushered his, Lee Tenghui, into office.16 And so, as the new century opened, peaceful democratisation took place in Taiwan, with the Guomindang conceding ground in successive clean elections, while in China the breakthrough has not come and the Communist Party clings to power.

It was the confident view of leading Guomindang liberal Shaw Yu-ming, in 1985, that China could and would reform itself. It was the conviction of the recalcitrant Iron Blood Patriots, hardline Guomindang rightists, at the same time, that Chiang Ching-kuo had gone soft on the democratic opposition. He should, they asserted bitterly, have done what his father would have done thrown the democratic oppositionists "into the sea". Chiang Ching-kuo, raised as a Leninist, tempered as a Stalinist, seasoned as an anti-Communist secret police chief, chose instead, at the end of a long political life, to throw Leninism into the sea. And when his old classmate, Deng Xiaoping, wrote to him in the last decade of his life, urging that they work together to reunify China, he replied that, while China remained as it was, this would mean "pouring spoiled wine into old bottles". The Chinese people, he declared to Deng's messengers,17 were sick of communism. They aspired, in its place, to freedom, democracy and prosperity. He could not give these things to China, but he did give them to Taiwan and, in doing so, he set a wonderful example to his old classmate. But Deng could not find it in himself or his party, in his last years, to follow that example.

In 1988, a six-part TV miniseries was screened in China, to great popular acclaim. It was called River Elegy. In it, the argument was advanced that Chinese political culture faced a profound choice. It could cling to all the imperial traditions symbolised by the Yellow River, which was drying up, and the Great Wall, which was an old ruin representing unsuccessful defensiveness against the outside world. Or it could look to the deep blue sea, from which the democracy and science and industry of the modern world had come and embrace an open future instead of a xenophobic past. The Communist Party reacted badly to the program and it was suppressed even before the disastrous events of June 1989. Like Bo Yang, however, the makers of that TV series were speaking the truth. It is a truth whose time has come and which might best be expressed in a new TV miniseries called Island Elegy.

Island Elegy would take up where River Elegy left off. It might begin with the statement by Yao Chia-wen, then chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party, in 1988: Taiwan is not part of China, but an island which stands at the intersection of the world's greatest continent and the world's greatest ocean. At that intersection, Taiwan now embodies the challenge to China and everything regressive in its political culture that Bo Yang identified in his Iowa speech. A precise measure of whether China can rise to that challenge will be the manner in which it chooses to deal with the island in the next decade or two. Will it, like the Guomindang in the 1940s and 1950s, seek to impose its will by force and censorship? Or will it, like Chiang in the 1980s, give up Ts'an-min Chu-I for San Min Chu-I, eschew threats and recognise the rights, dignity and freedom of the opposition? Gazing out from the Green Island memorial at the deep blue of the Pacific Ocean, one can see that the better of these choices is possible for the Communist leadership, as it was for the Guomindang leadership. The greatest task in the Chinese world in the years ahead is to draw them in that direction.

T06</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>PREVIEWS</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>ELEANOR SPRAWSON, KATE MINOGUE, CAROLINE BELLINGER, SCOTT JENKINS, CHELSEA HUNTER, MIRANDA HERRON, PENELOPE CROSS</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">WEDNESDAY DECEMBER 15</p><p nitf:lede="true">ELEANOR SPRAWSON</p><p nitf:lede="true">Where there's a Jill</p><p nitf:lede="true">Outback Jack</p><p nitf:lede="true">Nine, 9.30pm</p><p nitf:lede="true">They are rich, they are pampered and, God love them, they are optimistic.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Twelve American princesses on this new dating show are delighted when they are told that they will fly to Australia to meet an eligible bachelor and compete for his affections.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Asked what she expects from Down Under, one of them squeals, "Wine and caviar and mansions and everything".</p><p nitf:lede="true">You just know she and her friends are being set up something awful - and you can't look away. This is woefully bad television at its very, very best.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>It follows the tears, the heartache and the bad hair days that occur when the women are dropped (literally, by parachute) into the West Australian outback to vie for the attention of Outback Jack, who is a cross between Steve Irwin and the Anzac spirit.</p><p>The madness starts very early on, right from the moment when the women fly in from the States and are greeted at the airport by host J.D. Roberto with the words, "Welcome to Sydney, Australia" as he stands in front of one of Mascot's famous "canefields".</p><p>However, as it turns out that Mr Outback Jack does seem like a nice guy and once the real characters come out from behind the pampered caricatures, the series becomes genuinely engaging.</p><p>Surfing the Menu</p><p>ABC, 8pm</p><p>The first series of this show, which screened here last summer, has been the ABC's most successful export apart from Kath & Kim.</p><p>The international appeal is probably uncomfortably close to the appeal overseas of Outback Jack - gorgeously-shot landscapes and a good dose of knockabout Aussie blokey-ness.</p><p>Here presenters Curtis Stone and Ben O'Donoghue do seem to try just a bit too hard to be "Aussie" as opposed to just being themselves. But like last series, you'll find yourself forgiving them all their surfer-dude antics when they start cooking.</p><p>Tonight, in the first episode of a new series, the boys travel around the Cairns highlands and cook up all sorts of delights with the local produce including a freshwater crayfish risotto that looks not just scrumptious but actually doable at home.</p><p>The Medici</p><p>SBS, 8.30pm</p><p>The second episode of an eye-opening, four-part look at the role of the Medici family in the Renaissance in Florence follows the extraordinary life of Lorenzo, dubbed The Magnificent.</p><p>In between breathtakingly courageous acts of diplomacy which saved the independence of his family's beloved city, Lorenzo was a passionate scholar of humanism and encouraged artists like Botticelli to explore pagan subjects such as the Birth of Venus (pictured above).</p><p>In his spare time he discovered a young Michelangelo and managed to survive a conspiracy to wipe out the Medici by attacking them at Mass on Easter Sunday, in which his beloved brother was stabbed to death under the famous dome of Florence's cathedral.</p><p>Family Plots</p><p>Seven, 11pm</p><p>Like the British series The Office, it's hard to say whether this is comedy, drama or pure tragedy.</p><p>It is certainly a gem, and deserves better treatment from Channel 7.</p><p>Centred around a family-run mortuary in California, its tension and drama come from its painfully-real depiction of family relationships.</p><p>It's hard to think of another series that has ever done life's casual cruelties and the things that are left unsaid more acutely.</p><p>THURSDAY DECEMBER 16</p><p>KATE MINOGUE</p><p>Savin' their bacon</p><p>The Legend of the Tamworth Two</p><p>ABC, 8.30pm</p><p>At the outset you should know this is not about a pair of bushrangers from Tamworth in northern NSW. It does sound like that though, doesn't it? No it is actually about a couple of ginger pigs who escape an abattoir in the pretty English countryside.</p><p>Just like in the movie Look Who's Talking, the pigs chatter away to each other in English and you can't help but cheer them on as they continue to avoid capture by the humans.</p><p>The story of Butch and Sundance, as they were known, is actually based on truth.</p><p>The two fugitive pigs grabbed newspaper headlines in the UK while fleeing the police, their owner, the abattoir and a media pack for an entire week in 1998.</p><p>Tonight's tale is fun for the whole family.</p><p>The pigs are running for their lives and they doubt whether anyone cares. Ironically, it's the policeman in charge of the hunt - a vegetarian - who always lets them escape.</p><p>Getting to eavesdrop on the pigs' conversations is a treat. On one occasion when smelling bacon frying in a kitchen nearby, they ask, "Are we getting sunburnt?"</p><p>There's also a funny scene when the pair wake up hungover in the tent of some startled campers. By this time a creepy wolf-man has joined the chase and the entire nation is in a frenzy over their freedom.</p><p>Hope and Faith</p><p>Seven, 8pm</p><p>This is one silly show about two ditsy sisters who live together with a husband and some children.</p><p>There's nothing irregular going on though. Faith is just crashing long-term with her sister Hope and her family.</p><p>Tonight Hope's husband Charley (Ted McGinley, pictured with co-star Faith Ford) thinks he is finally getting rid of his annoying sister-in-law.</p><p>The Amazing Race</p><p>Seven, 8.30pm</p><p>This is such an exciting show the hour it's on TV passes in a flash. It is surprising how a series based on racing from one clue to another around the world can be so gripping.</p><p>Of course sometimes the challenges are awesome, like tonight, but really it's the characters who animate the show and compel you to sit glued to the screen.</p><p>There are four couples left in the race. The first task requires one person from each pair to climb more than 21m up a rope ladder to the girders beneath the road on the Auckland Harbour Bridge.</p><p>They have to walk across a beam high above the water to receive their next clue. What a nightmarish exercise.</p><p>Colin completes the job easily so he and Christie believe they're home free.</p><p>The others, understandably, find this task really "intimidating". But Colin and Christie have been too cocky.</p><p>By the end Colin is standing in a muddy field yelling "I hate you" at Christie.</p><p>You can see their post-show relationship is destined for the dumpster.</p><p>Meanwhile, it has been so satisfying to see "The Bowling Moms", Karen and Linda, taking on challenge after challenge and doing themselves proud.</p><p>As they say, "Moms can do anything". Bravo.</p><p>Scrubs</p><p>Seven, 11pm</p><p>The doctors and nurses in this hospital show do little that resembles medicine.</p><p>But it is good to see some sorely needed comedy, even if it is so frivolous.</p><p>The highlight is a scene that involves the trickery of modern mobile phones.</p><p>A woman sticks a camera phone under her shirt and takes a picture of her breasts as a way to maintain a longdistance relationship.</p><p>The man receiving the pic is so impressed he bumps smack bang into a telegraph pole.</p><p>It's pretty funny.</p><p>FRIDAY DECEMBER 17</p><p>CAROLINE BELLINGER</p><p>Six and the cities</p><p>Lonely Planet: Six Degrees</p><p>SBS, 7.30pm</p><p>Parisians, it seems, are entirely eccentric.</p><p>How else do you explain characters like Gaspard Delanoe, a shabby, junk bike-riding artiste who leads one of the city's most audacious squats? He "liberates" real estate by breaking into disused buildings and using them as makeshift studios until the police evict him.</p><p>Then there's Jacques Remus, a sound sculptor who makes music from washing machines and other industrial curiosities.</p><p>These and several other wonderful personalities feature in tonight's premiere of Lonely Planet's new project, Six Degrees.</p><p>Each week one of two presenters (in tonight's case, Toby Amies) travel to some of the world's most happening cities and immerse themselves in local culture.</p><p>They arrive with just one point of contact who leads them to another and so on. It's a real-life version of the popular game that proves we are more connected than we think.</p><p>Tonight, Amies is guided around Paris by socialite Emmanuel de Brantes who, while wearing an camouflage print cap and a straight face, tells the host he needs to get a sense of chic.</p><p>And apparently, if we are super-friendly and polite and pepper conversation with plenty of "mercis", then Parisians will be open to us in return. We can only hope.</p><p>Seinfeld</p><p>Ten, 7pm</p><p>Ah, how much sweeter life is when the'Feld is on TV.</p><p>It's the cream in your coffee, the icing on the cake, the kebab shop still open at 3am on your way home from a big night out on the town.</p><p>Tonight, when a fellow passenger on a flight falls ill, Jerry is left to care for Farfel, the man's dog.</p><p>When the owner finally returns to collect Farfel, he threatens to sue Jerry for "ruining" his prized pooch.</p><p>Meanwhile George and Elaine (Julia Louis-Dreyfus) try and spend time together without Jerry and, yada yada yada, they realise they have nothing to talk about.</p><p>French Leave</p><p>ABC, 8pm</p><p>Not quite travel show, almost cooking show, mostly reality show, this little delight takes us into the world of English chef John Burton-Race (pictured), his wife Kim and their six children.</p><p>Fed up with his life as a top chef, John has packed up the tribe and shipped out to rural France where he hopes they will live their dream.</p><p>Unfortunately, John and Kim share differing opinions of what that dream is.</p><p>So while John obsesses over soft cheeses, crusty breads and perfecting various regional French dishes, Kim revels in her love for expensive antique chairs.</p><p>This, as you can imagine, causes endless conflict.</p><p>Tonight, matters are not improved by the arrival of Kim's stubborn mother, Patsy.</p><p>"I want to kill somebody and I know that's probably illegal," John admits in a private moment with the camera.</p><p>Doc Martin</p><p>ABC, 8.30pm</p><p>Why is it that the darndest things always happen in English seaside towns? (Think Julian, Dick, Anne, George, Timmy the dog and their zany Famous Five adventures).</p><p>As such, this telemovie has more than its fair share of oddities.</p><p>Martin Clunes is Dr Martin Bamford, an obstetrician who discovers his wife has been sleeping with three of his friends.</p><p>In a moment of clarity, he escapes to Port Isaac on the coast of Cornwall and winds up working on a lobster boat.</p><p>Here, among the town's tight-knit community, he finds residents who roadtest grave sites, a GP who prescribes dog food and a phantom who delivers jelly to wrongdoers.</p><p>Expect plenty of laughs.</p><p>SATURDAY DECEMBER 18</p><p>SCOTT JENKINS</p><p>Yule be singing too</p><p>CAROLS IN THE DOMAIN</p><p>Seven, 8.30pm</p><p>There are three definite signs on TV that Christmas is upon us: your favourite shows are replaced by repeats; that annoying Chrisco woman keeps urging us to save for next year's Chrissy hamper; and Carols In the Domain.</p><p>The show, now in its 22nd year and sponsored by The Daily Telegraph, has become a last-Saturday-night-before-Christmas tradition and provides a much-cherished evening for all the family.</p><p>A quick perusal of the guest list means we should be in for a good night. The most talented of the Daddo brothers, Andrew, is sure to do another sterling job as host, aided by champion dancer Bec Cartwright.</p><p>Australian Idol contestant Cosima de Vito will sing (All I Want For Christmas Is A Music Career perhaps?) and Dancing With The Stars' favourite judge Todd McKenney will put his money where his mouth is and show us what he's capable of.</p><p>The cast from The Producers are on the bill while Idol No.1 Guy Sebastian, Lee Kernaghan The Wiggles, Rachel Beck and Andrew O'Keefe will also perform.</p><p>Oh, and Santa too.</p><p>You have yourselves a cool Yule, folks.</p><p>THE FUTURE IS WILD</p><p>SBS, 6pm</p><p>Science has shown how animals have evolved over millions of years.</p><p>Now, for the first time, this brilliant show applies the same principles and asks what sort of animals will likely inhabit the earth millions of years from now?</p><p>Using computer technology, we're introduced to fanciful creatures such as shagrats, snowstalkers and gannetwhales. This is the first of 13 parts of what is a totally fascinating series for anyone with a curious mind.</p><p>A wonderful concept and a wonderful show.</p><p>HIMALAYA WITH</p><p>MICHAEL PALIN</p><p>ABC, 7.30pm</p><p>Having already reviewed this wonderful show twice, it's hard for me to come up with more superlatives with which to praise it.</p><p>Suffice to say, this final episode is as entertaining and breathtaking as the rest and it's quite sad the journey has come to an end.</p><p>Tonight's final leg takes Michael Palin (pictured) from the almost mythical Kingdom of Bhutan all the way through to the Bay of Bengal (the home of The Phantom to us).</p><p>Gorgeous photography, witty narration from an amiable presenter and absolutely unique characters.</p><p>What more could you ask from Saturday night viewing?</p><p>Don't miss it.</p><p>HOLIDAY HOMES</p><p>FROM HELL</p><p>Lifestyle Channel (Foxtel/Optus), 10pm</p><p>Have you ever rented or purchased a holiday home?  If so you'll already know how much small inconveniences can help to really ruin the experience. The hot water may not work, the roof may leak. Or the police may arrest you for growing opium in your new backyard.</p><p>Despite its sensationalist title, this often-hilarious program offers cautionary tales of what happens when unscrupulous property developers set their sights on innocent Brits who buy an overseas getaway house.</p><p>Some of the cases are actually unbelievable.</p><p>There's Dr Gillis and his wife who fall victim to Italy's drug syndicates.</p><p>Mr and Mrs Eyres settle in for a quiet life on Crete, only to have their home swallowed up by a decades-long land dispute.</p><p>Then there's the James family, who find themselves the victims of a robbery and a forest fire in the same week.</p><p>SUNDAY DECEMBER 19</p><p>CHELSEA HUNTER</p><p>The Carnie folk capers</p><p>Carnivale</p><p>ABC, 8.30pm</p><p>Brothers and sisters, beware, for the end is nigh. At least, that is what Carnivale would have us believe. This US miniseries, which won five Emmys, is a revelation of sorts.</p><p>But with its deliberate pace, it requires your absolute patience and attention.</p><p>It sets up a whole load of questions that will leave you looking quizzically at your couch partner, then take its time answering them. But stick with it, for Carnivale will have people discussing the signs and plot twists at bus stops and dinner tables.</p><p>Carnivale is set in Depression-era America, with a young man, Ben Hawkins (Nick Stahl), burying his mother just moments before the bulldozers knock down his farmhouse and the cops appear on the horizon to take him back to the big house.</p><p>He is saved from his fate by The Carnies  led by Samson (Michael J. Anderson) - a ragtag bunch of performers with stout hearts and a link to the hereafter.</p><p>Ben has a talent that makes him every bit as unusual as the bearded lady and blind "mentalist" and, much to his discomfort, he fits in with these folk.</p><p>His gift, along with the pseudo-Gothic tones of this show, its references to pestilence, disease and plague and its freaky preacher man will slowly but surely draw you in.</p><p>Sabrina The</p><p>Teenage Witch</p><p>Ten, 6.30pm</p><p>The original Archie comic upon which this show is based had sweet, all-American values and jolly, gentle stories.</p><p>It was perfect to read while sucking on a Wizz Fizz.</p><p>Similarly this show, which has gone back to the first series when Sabrina (Melissa Joan Hart) and Harvey (Nate Richert) are still making goofy eyes at each other, has kept that fun, innocent vibe.</p><p>Tonight we see how the Spellmans celebrate Halloween (it involves clones) and how to fix a dateless Friday night (man dough).</p><p>Amba: The</p><p>Siberian Tiger</p><p>ABC, 7.30pm</p><p>If you have read Yann Martel's The Life Of Pi you will have a special interest in watching this documentary.</p><p>The Siberian tiger, much like Pi's Bengal tiger, is an awe-inspiring creature of true power and beauty.</p><p>They may be pretty kitties (as pictured) but with their massive paws and teeth that could easily skewer a limb, these are certainly not domesticated pets.</p><p>The documentary meanders a little in its attempts to show how endangered the tigers are by interviewing the people who are actively involved in keeping their numbers safe.</p><p>But despite the fascinating subject matter, it feels a little like an educational tool, the kind that would put you to sleep during high-school social studies.</p><p>Give it a few minutes though. You'll be impressed by the animals, if not the show.</p><p>Home On Their Own</p><p>Lifestyle Channel (Foxtel/Optus), 7.30pm</p><p>A father looks dejectedly at the camera. "My son," he sighs, "won't eat carrots out of a tin. He won't eat chips."</p><p>A son who wants a healthy diet - you can feel his pain, can't you?</p><p>While Dr Gillian McKeith would be doing jumping star-jacks for joy, this isn't her program. No, this is the show where kids send their parents away and get to redecorate parts of the house.</p><p>Nathan, 16, and Tobias, 12, have chosen to go a little Japanese in the kitchen, lounge room and their parents' bedroom. But you get the feeling the clean, healthy Zen lifestyle isn't going to go down well with their folks.</p><p>How times have changed.</p><p>MONDAY DECEMBER 20</p><p>MIRANDA HERRON</p><p>The youth is out there</p><p>Nip/Tuck</p><p>Nine, 9.30pm</p><p>Plastic surgeons, in the US at least, are becoming superstars and Nip/Tuck is a drama which luridly imagines what might go on behind the scenes in the lives of these modern gods.</p><p>What the show portrays is certainly not pretty. There's narcissism, self-doubt, greed, emotional paralysis and empty (and frequent) sexual encounters, all jumbled in with the flash cars, gleaming minimal offices and beautiful women.</p><p>Nip/Tuck revolves around the dysfunctional lives of two top Miami surgeons, Sean (Dylan Walsh) and Christian (Julian McMahon), and aims for sensation rather than realism.</p><p>But it goes beyond mere trash by delving into the deeper, darker concepts of ageing, self-esteem, dependency and - if it's not going too far - even the meaning of life.</p><p>In the season return, Sean develops "the yips", a tremor in his operating hand caused by turning 40 and contemplating how a plastic surgeon is supposed to age in an ageist society.</p><p>Each episode focuses on a new patient so it doesn't become too bogged down with the main characters' neuroses.</p><p>There is also some stomach-turning surgery, including, in the second of two episodes tonight, Christian attempting to give himself a nose job with a chisel and hammer.</p><p>Summerland</p><p>Ten, 7.30pm</p><p>Ryan Kwanten (pictured) played the ill-fated Vinnie who ended up behind bars on soapie Home & Away In this new Aaron Spelling family drama, he plays likeable Aussie surfer, Jay.</p><p>He is one of three adult friends who move into a rambling beach house to help Ava (Lori Loughlin) when she inherits three children after her sister's death.</p><p>The storylines of the show are not revolutionary but it is saved from being hopelessly soppy and artificial by the adult characters.</p><p>Far from being Brady Bunch cardboard cut-outs, they drink beer in the spa in the evening and have diverse views on parenting which makes it more interesting than the standard nuclear-family drama.</p><p>In this episode Ava finds a joint in teenage Brandin's (Jesse McCartney) bag. She admits she's had a puff in the past and Jay says his parents found his stash and smoked it with him. Collectively they have to grapple with how to approach the issue of drugs without being hypocritical.</p><p>Origins: Where</p><p>Are The Aliens?</p><p>SBS, 7.30pm</p><p>Apparently it took half a billion years for intelligent life to evolve on earth.</p><p>According to some, the conditions on earth which allowed this to occur are so "wacky weirdo" they are unlikely to be found anywhere else in the universe.</p><p>Others such as radio astronomer Frank Drake, inventor of the Drake Equation which predicts whether planets are capable of sustaining life, are convinced there is life out there somewhere.</p><p>You don't have to be an astrophysicist to understand this interesting doco which explores the arguments for and against other lifeforms.</p><p>It also explains, quite helpfully, why we and the aliens may be having such difficulty finding each other.</p><p>Family Story: the Company You Keep</p><p>ABC, 8pm</p><p>Mental illness affects many Australians but it's not a high profile or sexy issue.</p><p>The profound effects on a sufferer's family are often overlooked too.</p><p>This simple and short doco chronicles a very small slice of life for the family of Ally, a young woman with a depressive psychosis.</p><p>It's remarkable to see how resilient the family is in the face of such sadness.</p><p>TUESDAY DECEMBER 21</p><p>PENELOPE CROSS</p><p>Rose maketh the man</p><p>Rose And Maloney</p><p>ABC, 8.30pm</p><p>She drinks like a fish, smokes like a chimney and once had a sordid affair with her boss.</p><p>And ironically for Rose (Sarah Lancashire), an investigator for an organisation that looks into possible miscarriages of justice, she has been paired with a colleague whose biggest regret in life was the time he missed an exam.</p><p>But it's the lack of things Rose has in common with nerdy administrative manager Maloney (Phil Davis) that make their on-screen chemistry so humorous.</p><p>Rose has dragged former backroom boy Maloney into an unofficial investigation of the case of David McVay (Tony Maudsley), a man jailed for killing his daughter.</p><p>The fiesty redhead believes the evidence doesn't add up - mainly because there's a distinct lack of it and the shifty-looking cops never found a body.</p><p>Unfortunately however, Rose's tendency to ruffle a few feathers has already gotten Maloney into a car accident, ruined his VW and made his face all splotchy.</p><p>In tonight's episode - the second part of the show's pilot - she even convinces him it's possible to "look inconspicuous" while driving her filthy red and blue Range Rover.</p><p>Rose has, of course, lost her licence.</p><p>Yep, she's a bossy boots and he loves the field work, though he's loathe to admit it.</p><p>The O.C.</p><p>Ten, 8.30pm</p><p>It may only be filming its second season but The O.C. has already spawned three soundtracks. Or, as an elite circle of fans refer to them - "The CDs".</p><p>But that's not to say all these mixes are worthy of being in Seth Cohen's (Adam Brody) personal emo collection.</p><p>The weakest link is undoubtedly an album of corny cover tracks dubbed Have A Very Merry Chrismukkah.</p><p>Yet the episode from which the complilation stems is actually rather fabulous and screens tonight - The Best Chrismukkah Ever.</p><p>For the uninitiated, Chrismukkah is a family holiday in the Jewish and Christian Cohen household.</p><p>Footballers' Wives</p><p>Ten, 9.30pm</p><p>There are moments in the opening scene of this episode where the cameraman appears to have absent-mindedly filmed the back of someone's head.</p><p>But it is probably a tactic to disguise the fact the actors are fighting back laughter.</p><p>And who could blame Ian (Nathan Constance) and Donna (Katharine Monaghan, pictured above, right) from giggling when Ian walks in on his wife with her lover?</p><p>He is furious but Donna just holds up an old copy of The Sun she happens to have handy where, plastered on the front page, is a picture of Ian having a threesome with two lap dancers.</p><p>Then there was that affair he had with her sister.</p><p>Meanwhile, Tanya (Zoe Lucker, pictured, centre) is livid when Jason (Cristian Solimeno) wants to give his baby godson (who is, of course, secretly his son) money for a good education.</p><p>Why is she mad? Well she could have spent that on a weekend shopping in Milan.</p><p>This show, is just too wonderfully trashy and fun for words.</p><p>The West Wing</p><p>Nine, 10.30pm</p><p>You really have to admire the multi-tasking that takes place on this great show.</p><p>It's so fast paced that the characters are often required to conduct discussions of importance in the corridors of the White House on their way to the toilet.</p><p>OK, well not quite but in tonight's episode, the hallways do seem a rather odd place to debate candidates for the vice presidency.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P0N-JTX0-TXN5-S2NY-00000-00The day the earth caught fire2006-03-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:50ZLexisNexisGOOD WEEKENDPg. 22The day the earth caught fireDEVASTATIONJOHN VAN TIGGELEN

It's high summer in Victoria. The landscape is tinder-dry, seared by scorching temperatures and wild northerlies. With conditions like these, in one of the most bushfire-prone places on the planet, an inferno is inevitable. John van Tiggelen reports from the front line.

The morning after Victoria's worst day of fire in three summers, Sandi Murdoch and her menagerie of injured and orphaned bush critters are seeing off a second onslaught. First a bushfire went through her refuge. Now comes the media pack, in search of ground zero. The January 22 fires have wiped out much and are far from done yet, but the so-called Anakie fire, which has already consumed half the Brisbane Ranges National Park, is the most accessible to Melbourne. Also, the commercial news networks are insisting that between 15 and 20 homes around Anakie, an hour west of Melbourne, have been burnt to the ground, with the result that reporters are almost indecently concentrated around the few that actually were.

Murdoch's brick-veneer box, baking behind charred trees and a flame-blistered Land for Wildlife sign, isn't quite one of them. There are more dramatic scenes both across the road and around the corner, where the carcasses of beautiful homes lie wrapped around their chimneys. But everyone loves a quirky story in a day of drama, and Murdoch's tale, about having rescued her animals by moving them from their pens into her home, dovetails nicely. There's a roo in her bed and a koala draped on the curtain rod. A second bedroom is filled with chickens, a third sleeps orphaned joeys in slings, the bathroom is a-squawk with caged galahs and cockatoos and the lounge room is squirming with bagged koalas and possums.

Says Murdoch: "I've got no reason to be upset, have I? I've got my home and the animals are okay."

In the back of her "animal ambulance" are three singed fugitives she retrieved from nearby properties that morning. More koalas, one with a "cooked" eye. Cameras roll and snap. Then everyone goes off in search of blacker pastures.

Yet Murdoch's tale is something. Joined only by her brother John, a burly bay fisherman, she faced a fire that had everyone else, neighbours and firefighters included, on the run. Spurred on by 40kmh northerlies, 43-degree heat and humidity in the low teens, the fire, which Murdoch glimpsed as "a roll of black smoke against a red background", leapt the road to lay waste to her aviaries and animal enclosures, incinerate her car, melt an aluminum lean-to and whoosh through the tree canopies around the house before snap-frying a koala in an ironbark and destroying two homes further down the ridge.

Neither Sandi, 59, nor her brother recall feeling fear. "We were busy," she says. "There wasn't time," he says. "We could only run and put out the flames that were shooting up everywhere, on the bark, the ground. The heat was unbelievable; I had on a flannelette shirt, jeans and a woollen beanie, plus a wet towel on my back that would dry in seconds. Sandi kept hosing me down.

"The wind was swirling; it was like there were eddies. The flames were above the shed. Then we saw the fire crowning [igniting the canopy] in the trees and Sandi called me inside. We shut the door, grabbed a wet blanket and pulled it over our heads.

"You should have heard the smoke alarms," he says. "She had three! They set off the rooster; it was going off over the top of them. It was driving me crazy but there was no time to do anything about it. After a minute, two tops, I opened the door, saw it was okay and we ran back out to mop up the flames."

No fire crews arrived to help. "And we didn't expect them," Sandi Murdoch says matter-of-factly. "We've had it drilled into us the past few years that if we're going to live here, we have to plan for fire. That we can't rely on the fire brigade because they can't always come.

So we had a plan."

"I told her she had to get rid of the trees around her house," says her brother. "She said, 'No, it's the bush. If I cut the trees I may as well live in town.' So we just stuck to the plan. To be honest, part of me wanted to test it out. To see if it worked." He looks at his sister as if conceding a minor point. "It worked."

"It did," she says.

"Just," he says.

A flammable country is going to burn at some point. Come January 22, a Sunday, the Country Fire Authority (CFA) knows what it is in for. The state is tinder-dry. As early as the previous Tuesday, forecasters predicted a forest fire danger index (FFDI) of 86, well over the threshold required for a total fire ban. (Anything over 50 is considered "extreme".) Desiccating northerlies would push temperatures into the low 40s ahead of a vicious westerly change. Most worryingly, it's next to inevitable that bush is already burning following overnight electrical storms.

If the forecast were for a cyclone, it would be a category four - Cyclone Tracy strength. The day dawns ominously hot. Country racing is cancelled at Stony Creek. ABC Radio's cricket coverage is suspended in favour of fire updates. And in Melbourne, all matches at the Australian Open are cancelled save those under cover.

I spend the day at the CFA's Melbourne headquarters, from where it co-ordinates its army of almost 60,000 volunteers and 2300 red trucks. Expecting an office, I walk into a war room. Desks are arranged, theatre style, around an enormous screen. The screen features a map of Victoria displaying "enemy" details - the enemy being the weather - such as wind direction and speed, temperature and humidity levels. On either side of the map are panels listing current "incidents", including their size, status and the amount of hardware (trucks and helicopters) deployed.

"We know we're having a bad day if those two panels are full by the end of the day," the CFA's media co-ordinator, Alex Twomey, tells me. It's 11am and they already are. There are some 90 fires listed, the worst of them running riot in the Grampians, Bessiebelle, Tyrendarra, Edenhope and Mount Misery. (Just as the War on Terror teaches George W. Bush geography, so the War on Fire serves to teach it to Australians.) By noon, media reports are coming in of homes lost near Portland and Moe, at opposite ends of the state.

By order of the chief that morning, all staff are kitted out in yellow bibs identifying their position. "This day is shaping as one we'll remember," says Russell Rees, whose bib reads "chief officer". "Essentially the fire is not controllable. Our game is about controlling the firefight."

In country Victoria, firefighting falls to two organisations: the CFA, whose brief is to protect private property, and the Department of Sustainability and Environment, which looks after public land - that is, the bush. Although most large fires start in bushland, and are therefore the responsibility of the department, it's the CFA that is left to flex its muscle if the fires run truly wild.

Rees is a balding, fatherly figure who forever looks as if he's eagerly leaning forwards, even while walking. His posture is possibly born of a lifetime spent peering at maps. Having seen the same slabs of bush burn twice or more since starting as a junior firefighter at 11 in the Latrobe Valley, he has a peerless grasp of Victorian geography.

"It's not shitful but it's pretty close," he says, looking at the central map. "People out there will think it is, but what I'm saying is it's not catastrophic. So far" - he looks at his watch - "at 1.30, we're doing okay. But it's only 1.30."

One of the key tasks at CFA HQ - one that has been reinforced by the disastrous Canberra fires of 2003 - is to use information to minimise risk. The emphasis is on warning of what might happen, rather than revealing what already has. Often that means it's slower than media reportage - for instance, the day's CFA statements have yet to acknowledge that houses have been lost. Occasionally this also means it's right - no houses have actually been lost as yet; they turned out to be haysheds.

"It's the fog of war," says Twomey. "We have these moments when, bang, no one knows what's going on and we just have to sit tight. I equate this business [of getting the information out] with making sausages. You really don't want to see how people do it - I mean, it's mayhem here - but if you look at our website, it's a job well done." He calls up the website. Unfortunately, it's attracting so many hits, it's jammed.

About two o'clock, word comes through that the blaze in the Brisbane Ranges, near Anakie, classed as "contained" overnight and patrolled by just 12 trucks according to the screen, is going like the clappers. The regional commander phones to say it's scaring his men and can't be stopped: flying embers are "spotting" (creating spot fires) 200 metres ahead of the fire front and tree canopies are crowning 100 metres ahead. Someone produces a map and draws a teardrop, representing the likely fire path. "That's a dangerous spot," says the chief, leaning in. "If it gets into there" - he pricks his pen at a spray of little black squares marking homes in the bush - "that's a lot of people under threat."

More strike-teams (comprising five trucks each) are instantly dispatched. The trick to moving strike-teams around the state is not to compromise the safety of their regions of origin. Says Rees: "Even now, we've still got 1000 trucks on the ground, dealing with the day-to-day: house fires, car fires, kids with their bloody fingers stuck in plug-holes."

But now the time has come to put in a call for assistance to the South Australian fire chief. "We're shitful," Rees tells him. "The board's lit up like a Christmas tree. We're not struggling yet, but it will come." However, South Australia has few men to spare because it's ablaze as well. So is Tasmania. "We can't really move stuff around now," the chief says. "Every aircraft is committed. It's a case of everyone dealing with what they've got."

By 3.15pm, despite seven choppers and 46 trucks on hand, there are unconfirmed reports of houses ablaze near Anakie. Elvis, the American air crane which carries up to five times as much water as an average chopper, is called in to help, as is the Metropolitan Fire Brigade.

The news from elsewhere is similarly grim. It's raining ash on several towns bordering the Grampians. A helicopter has crash-landed in Gippsland. The Tyrendarra fire has jumped Highway One. Around the state, smoke from surrounding fires is hanging over Horsham, Warrnambool, the Latrobe Valley, Ballarat, Bendigo and Geelong. Says Twomey: "A journo just rang asking which fire she should go to.

I said, 'Drive in any direction you want.'"

A little after seven, as I'm about to leave, Rees's deputy calls the media team to a snap meeting. His face is grave: "We've just received news that we've lost 18 houses in De Motts Road, in the Brisbane Ranges. We've sent police out for confirmation and to check no one's in them." He pauses. "It's consistent with what we've been saying. And she's still going. ... We need to slow the information flow. We don't want people to run back in."

Driving to Geelong across the West Gate Bridge, the light is an eerie cellophane yellow. Westerly gusts bounce cans and branches across the freeway. Overhead the sky blackens. The blanket of smoke that had been billowing over Geelong has been flung eastwards, leaving the usually benign You Yangs looking volcanic as smoke spews from the Brisbane Ranges somewhere behind them. On the radio, a CFA spokesman warns that the fire has jumped another control line and that further "assets may be impacted" in Staughton Vale, a community strung out along what was the fire's eastern flank, but is now its new front.

At the northern outskirts of Geelong, some 200 people from the Anakie district have gathered for an emergency meeting. Many are seized with panic by the scale of the pall overhead, and the thought that the ash falling around them might be their possessions.

On the lee side of a large hall, one of 10 emergency relief centres being set up around the state, people make feverish attempts to contact neighbours who stayed. One woman, her face flushed with heat and suffering, suddenly drops her phone and collapses in the arms of her parents. "The fire's only 100 metres from the house," she says. "The fruit trees are burning."

Inside, the cavernous brown-brick hall refuses to give up the day's heat. A battery of ceiling fans can only stir the soupy air. Under the harsh fluoro lights, fire-stricken families huddle in both hope and fear of answers, their eyes bloodshot from smoke, fatigue and worry.

A single mother called Cheryl tells me her kids were over the moon about seeing so many helicopters. A man called Doug rues leaving behind his fishing rods. Another woman, Lynnette, fled her home with her galah, two dogs and her husband's Harley on the trailer. It seems many husbands stayed. "He wouldn't come," says Joyce Giacometti of her elderly husband, Bruce. "We pleaded with him but he just wouldn't."

Among the tears and cheers, the fire is steadily animated into a mythical beast. It variously "turned feral", "outsmarted firies" or even "blew out its own arse". A CFA veteran, who'd discharged himself from hospital only to return home and be evacuated, declares "the fire's behaving like nothing I've ever seen".

A thin, kind-faced bureaucrat stands up to announce that crews are trying to contain

the fire at Old Boundary Road, well past Staughton Vale. "It looks a long way from where the fire was two hours ago and it is,"

he says, as several people slump their heads and those holding hands tighten their grip.

"At eight o'clock it had burnt out 2600 hectares, now it's 4500. We're not hopeful

of pulling it up in the next hour."

Next, someone gets up to offer free "pet and budgie" board. It's left to the local policeman to face the questions about which homes have been lost. Most people only evacuated when the police told them to. They have seen news footage of houses burning and heard up to 20 homes have been destroyed. But the constable has no answers. With his left hand nervously slapping into his right, he instead urges residents to stay the night with friends and family and await further news in the morning. "Do not go home," he says. "It's not safe. Remember that to lose your house is preferable to losing your life."

As the meeting winds to a close near midnight, he tells me, "I know they won't sleep tonight without knowing if they have a home to go back to. But we don't yet know if we'll find any deceased. Some of these homes are tucked right into the bush and we know there are people who stayed. Fact is, if they keep their properties clear, and they have a [bushfire] plan, we and the CFA encourage them to

stay." He fingers his moustache before adding: "That's the policy. As to whether it's wise ...

I have to say that from where I stand now, it's a bit of a worry."

Victoria is reputed to be the most fire-prone region in the world, marginally ahead of California, parts of the Mediterranean and the rest of south-eastern Australia. In the 40 years to 2001, the state accounted for more than half of the 224 deaths and $2.5 billion damages caused by bushfires in Australia. Climate change isn't helping. CSIRO modelling released last month shows that the number of days of very high to extreme fire danger will increase by up to 20 per cent across the south-eastern corner in the next two decades. As well as becoming more frequent, the worst days will get worse. By 2050, summers will be peppered with days like January 22. Which of those days will foment catastrophes - such as 1983's Ash Wednesday fires (2000 homes, 75 lives) or the Canberra fires of January 18, 2003 (500 homes, four lives) - is at the whim of lightning, arsonists or simple misfortune.

But it is inevitable there will be more. A national inquiry into bushfire management

in the wake of the Canberra fires concluded bushfires would increase in frequency, intensity and size. At best, authorities might hope to minimise the loss of lives and property. The Victorian high-country fires of 2003 are a case in point: born out of 87 lightning-lit fires one freak January day, they raged for two months to ravage 1.2 million hectares, or 5 per cent of the state. The good news was no one died.

Whether firefighting efforts can be beefed up to keep pace with global warming - read inland drying - is doubtful. Rural decline has put a strain on CFA resources in many of the most fire-prone regions. Also, the recent influx of "tree-changers" - city dwellers who have traded their rush hours for a country lifestyle - into rural communities such as Anakie has yet to be reflected in the make-up of local CFA volunteer ranks. It's an open question as to how long ageing farming communities will tolerate being called upon to save - for free - the designer homes and weekenders budding among the forested hills.

The morning after the battle for Anakie, red trucks bearing the names of other one-horse hamlets are parked 10 in a line from the town's general store, which squats opposite the fire station. Yellow-clad firies mill about jacketless, snacking, yawning, trading tales of battle and pointing with grim humour at a month-old shop window advertisement for a house up on the burnt ridge over town: "For Sale, Paradise Found. Idyllic Bush Setting."

Relief shines on soot-smudged faces. "I thought we were gone for a while there," remarks volunteer Shaun Davidge. "You could actually hear the crews cheering when Elvis arrived." Daybreak saw losses restricted to three homes, an outdoor education centre and several haysheds, with another three homes destroyed in part.

But it's not over yet. Some 40 truck crews are "blacking out" the fire perimeter (that is, backburning), and the short-wave crackles repeatedly with news of break-outs. Four choppers continue to ferry buckets to and fro. The fear is that the fire could erupt again on Thursday, Australia Day, forecast to be almost a carbon copy of yesterday. Returning residents are being told to decide now whether to stay.

For Nick Lanham and Bonnie Kohnert, who live on De Motts Road, it's a no-brainer. Their blackened house, two gates down from Sandi Murdoch's wildlife refuge, is now minus a kitchen, bathroom and bedroom. "We're out of here," says Nick. A posse of friends is helping cart what remains of the young couple's possessions into a large ute. When the ute radio mentions that the bodies of a father and son have been found in a car swept up in the Grampians fire, several pause to curse.

Back at the general store I run into Peter Stray, a local sheep farmer and brigade stalwart who began fighting the fire in the national park on Saturday morning, after it was sparked by lightning. That night he got home at 2am and slept badly, fearing that the park rangers' containment lines might not hold against Sunday's extreme weather conditions.

In the 36 hours since, he's managed just four hours' kip but he's keen to assess the damage. We set off in his white ute, equipped with a small tank, a pump and a hose.

He points to the north ridge overlooking Anakie. "The fire came crowning through the tops of the trees there. The Brisbane Ranges is stringy-bark country, and stringy-bark is the worst for spot fires. The embers fly for miles and miles."

The tankers fell back to hold their line just outside town. Then the change hit, creating a new front. We continue north towards Staughton Vale. "I'm not sure what's been lost up here," says Stray, steering a wide berth around a stretch of "widow-makers" - massive roadside river red gums still burning from the inside. We pass a place called Touchwood that had a lucky escape. Further on some sheds have been lost, as well as the Anakie Gorge picnic area, a house and a school. More striking than what's been lost is what's been saved. Intact farmhouses and their sentinel pines stand out like desert islands against seared paddocks. The ridges behind them bristle with eucalypt skeletons - not a leaf has been spared.

Stray's mobile rings. It's the regional chief wanting Stray to take charge of a third of the fire perimeter tonight, from 7pm to 7am. "Makes it hard to run a farm," he says after putting down his phone. In recent years he has been sent to fight fires on the NSW Central Coast and in East Gippsland. With a shrug he says, "You do have a choice but you feel you have to do your bit."

Stray also helps the CFA run its Community Fireguard program, which brings groups of residents together for a series of information sessions on fire survival. People are instructed to make their properties less fire-prone so they might stay and defend their homes rather than leaving them susceptible to wind-borne embers, which are by far the biggest cause of structural losses in bushfires. Several of Stray's "pupils" live here, in the fire zone.

"How did they go?" he wonders. "That's something I really want to look into: what people did, who stayed, who went and whose houses were saved as a result."

He knows very few stayed. He's not sure that, with all his awareness, he'd have stayed himself. "It's all about knowing to duck inside when the head fire is coming through, so you don't suffer the radiant heat. But having said that, imagine that orange, red, black cloud coming towards you. It would be really, really scary. Do you stay, or do you jump in the car at the last minute? We say if you're going to leave, leave early. But I wouldn't know what [staying] might be like."

He's silent for a while, then says: "I'm quite happy in my open country." The notion of a "bush lifestyle" perplexes him; it's something "trendies" do. "I wonder how many people will sell up now. A lot of these places already have a big turnover. They're all sold in the spring, when everything looks lovely. Come summer, it's just too hot and dry for them."

At Sandi Murdoch's refuge, Stray slows down. "These stringies" - he points at the stringy-barks hanging over her house - "that's just suicide. And see all the grass trees through there? They are incredible for producing heat. They have all those fronds and they're full of resin." He shakes his head. "You sure she stayed? She must have had a helicopter drop. How she didn't decide to make a run for it, even at the last minute ...

I think they're really brave. Really brave. Some might say foolhardy." (Later, Sandi Murdoch acknowledges she was lucky. "The heli-tanker guys sprayed the tree canopy out the back. If they hadn't, the fire might have come up at us from the gully as well.")

The next house is set in a clearing - it survived. Then comes Nick Lanham and Bonnie Kohnert's half-burnt home, tucked into a copse of ironbarks that leaves Stray aghast. "That's the worst I've seen," he says. The worst, that is, until we turn into the driveway of the lot opposite. A pile of remains is surrounded by scorched stringy-barks and grass-trees. Even the above-ground pool, likewise flanked by grass-tree stumps, has melted to the ground. The house, which must have been beautiful, with spectacular views towards the You Yangs, stood no chance.

"Whose house is this?" I ask Stray.

"The park ranger's," he says, deadpan.

The subdivisions strung along the ridge road once belonged to a single property. Paul Evans moved into the original 102-year-old home at the top of the ridge last year, with views over Geelong and the bay. As the fire approached he knew he was in no position to defend a weatherboard home on stumps. Any embers swirling underneath would ignite on contact. About two o'clock, under an intensely hot sky, he bundled his two peacocks into a cage he'd picked up that morning from Sandi Murdoch's place, popped them on a trailer and set off down his escape route, a bush track cutting south across his 60-hectare property to Murdoch's block.

"I knew Sandi and her brother were staying, so I stopped to help," says Evans. "It was fairly frantic but there was a procedure. We hosed around the house and did some last-minute chopping down of trees."

He had no way of knowing whether the fire had reached his house. He considered sheltering at Murdoch's but knew he'd likely be sacrificing his car at the very least. "Sandi's house is plain and solid with a low-pitched roof. It's the type of building that might survive. But even though they'd done a hell of a lot of work to make it safer, how safe is safer? Between my place and Sandi's, down in the gully, there's a dam with a five-metre jetty. The jetty burnt down to the water line - that's how hot it was." It also worried him to hear Murdoch's preparations went beyond mere survival: "She told me she was prepared to die with her animals."

About three o'clock, just as a row of trees crowned into flame on the other side of a paddock across the road, he wished Sandi and John luck and took off.

In town, he parked near the general store. There he ran into another of Murdoch's brothers, Keith, who'd been helping her prepare but ultimately wasn't game to stay. Every so often Keith would confirm his sister was still alive by ringing her to ask, "Have you suicided yet?" All she'd handed him for safekeeping was her will.

When embers began raining on Anakie, Evans drove to a nearby friend's place to watch the news. He'd seen the television choppers overhead and figured their footage of burning homes would reveal whether he still had one. Alas, the widespread power blackout kept him in the dark.

Roadblocks prevented him from returning until 11pm, when he was finally waved through. Two-thirds of the way up the ridge his car's high beam exposed the forest's new charred form. On both sides of the road, as far as the eye could see, naked grass trees glowed like candles. Passing Murdoch's place, he saw her car was incinerated. He drove slowly on through the debris. At his gate the intact letterbox gave him a flicker of hope. Then he saw the lone chimney, and, crumpled around it, the roof of his house.

"I stood there for about five minutes. I thought about all the renovating I'd done. I thought about the old floorboards. And then I thought, 'Well, that ought to have cleared up the white-ant problem.'"

The week of January 22 saw the deployment of 10,000 volunteer firefighters and 62 aircraft in Victoria. About 170,000 hectares and 30 homes were burnt. Two civilians and a volunteer firefighter died, along with some 63,000 sheep and 1000 cows.
