urn:contentItem:5564-G1J1-JD34-V523-00000-00THE BRADYS TARGET GUN LOBBY1991-04-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:50ZLexisNexisWEEKEND REVIEWPg. 29THE BRADYS TARGET GUN LOBBYWayne King Source: The New York Times

IT WAS not John Hinckley's murderous assault on President Reagan and her husband, Jim, in March 1981 that turned Sarah Brady into America's most implacable foe of easy access to handguns. It was her son, Scott.

It happened in 1985, in her husband's peaceful hometown of Centralia, Illinois. Scott, then 5 years old, crawled into a family friend's pickup truck, spied a plaything on the seat, picked it up and pointed it in fun at his mother.

"Don't do that, Scott," she said. "Don't ever point a gun at anyone, even a toy." She looked closer and paled. It was not a toy. It was a loaded .22 pistol, the same kind of $20 gun Hinckley used to shoot her husband.

The potential disaster brought everything crashing in on her. "I stormed about it for days and weeks," she says. "And then back in Washington I picked up the paper and saw the Senate was getting ready to vote on the McClure-Volkmer bill."

McClure-Volkmer - introduced by Republican James A. McClure of Idaho and Democrat Harold L. Volkmer of Missouri - was strongly backed by the National Rifle Association, which had long pushed to neutralise the Gun Control Act of 1968. The 1968 act wasn't an especially tough piece of legislation to begin with. It built on the National Firearms Act of 1934 and the Federal Firearms Act of 1938, and, among the restrictions, prohibited gun dealers from selling to minors and the importing of non-sporting weapons.

Even so, it in effect allowed any adult who wanted a hunting rifle to go down to the local gun store and buy one. You could buy a pistol with nothing more than proof of residence and your oath that you were not crazy or a convicted felon. Few people checked to see if you were telling the truth. You could buy a machine gun if you paid $200 for a Federal tax stamp, underwent a background check by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms and your local police chief didn't object.

But the Gun Control Act did require gun dealers to keep records of who bought firearms, in case the weapon they sold ended up being used to kill somebody. And it banned interstate and mail-order sales, like the one in which Lee Harvey Oswald bought, for $21.45, the 6.5-millimetre Mannlicher-Carcano he used to kill John F. Kennedy in 1963. But the 1968 act had long grated on the NRA and other proponents of easy access to firearms.

"McClure-Volkmer would have annihilated the 68 Act," says Sarah Brady. She was not then, nor is she now, hysterical about guns. Her father, an agent for the FBI, wore a .38 to work. He and her brother and uncles all hunted for sport, and Sarah Brady sees no evil in it. Her husband's boss, Ronald Reagan, was a member of the NRA; so is George Bush.

But her son had pointed a loaded pistol at her and the emotionally disturbed man who had shot her husband had had no difficulty buying guns or the kind of exploding bullets called Devastators. The bullets that hit the President, a policeman and a Secret Service agent did not explode; the one that entered Jim Brady's brain did.

They got Brady to George Washington University Hospital within 10 minutes and managed to save his life, sawing open his skull all the way across the forehead and getting out the fragments and doing other things like lancing his left eyelid to keep

the pressure from blinding him in case he did survive, which few thought likely. But he did, and although he walked out, literally, on November 23, 1981, both he and his wife knew he was badly, permanently, hurt.

He could only walk a few steps at a time and the pain was horrible. He cried and screamed and sometimes he would blank out and howl like an animal. After a year or so, he tried to write his name and it would come out JIMMMMMMMM, or he would count and it would go 1,2,3,3,3333333.

"But it was the summer that Scott got hold of the gun that really finished me," says Sarah Brady. "And then the McClure-Volkmer bill. I thought, 'This is ridiculous.' And I called Handgun Control Inc. and I said, 'Can I do anything to help?'

Charles Orasin, president of Handgun Control - a citizens group based in Washington that lobbies, in its words, "to keep handguns out of the wrong hands" - signed up Sarah Brady to write letters to members of the Senate, in which she urged them to

turn back the worst excesses of McClure-Volkmer. She also spoke to a number of the Senators in person. And she wrote about the issue for national newspapers.

But in May 1986 the McClure-Volkmer bill became law. For the NRA, though, it was a Pyrrhic victory. The organisation had spent millions in its efforts to roll back the 1968 act, and the concessions it won were less than they had worked to get. Gun dealers could sell, over the counter, certain guns to out-of-staters, as long as the sale was legal in the state of the buyer and seller. Dealers could now sell ammunition by mail, but not firearms. And a last-minute addition to the bill banned the further manufacture of machine guns for private sale and made conversions of semi-automatic weapons to machine guns more difficult.

The day after the bill was approved by Congress, the entire 17-member public relations staff of the NRA was summarily dismissed. The gun lobby denies that the dismissals and passage of the watered-down bill were connected.

ALTHOUGH the image of James Brady, face down on the sidewalk outside the Washington Hilton, haunted the debate that his wife carried to Congress in the mid-1980s, he himself stayed out of it.

For one thing, he was still technically the White House press secretary and would be until Reagan left office in early 1989. It was Brady's duty to keep his mouth shut. "Me and my boss really didn't see eye to eye on it," he says today. For another, it was Sarah Brady's cause, not his. On behalf of Handgun Control, she lobbied vigorously for legislation circumscribing the buying of firearms; he was concerned with the rights of the disabled.

Brady is unsure as to when he decided to break his silence on the issue of gun control.Certainly, having his name taken off the White House masthead in January 1989 had much to do with it. But once the decision was made he pursued the task with characteristic zeal. Despite his severe physical handicaps he travelled with his wife on about a dozen trips around the country pressing for gun control.

ON November 21, 1989, Jim Brady testified before a Senate judiciary subcommittee on behalf of Senate Bill 1236. The bill, which has been around since 1987 in various forms and was named after Jim and Sarah Brady, basically asks for a gun-purchase waiting period of seven days, during which time a background check of the purchaser can be made.

"Are you going to continue to pander to the special-interest groups that whine about a little inconvenience and other such lamebrain foolishness?" Jim Brady asked the subcommittee.

The first Handgun Control print advertisement featuring Jim Brady appeared early in 1990. "Ever since I was shot," it said, "I have watched from my wheelchair as the gun lobby blocked one sane handgun control bill after another. But I'm not just watching anymore. I'm calling on Congress to pass a commonsense law - the Brady Bill requiring a seven-day 'cooling off' period before the purchase of a handgun. So police have time to check if the buyer has a criminal record."

In the ad, Brady cited polls showing that 91 per cent of Americans - and 87 per cent of American handgun owners - support the bill, as does every major law-enforcement organisation in the country. In fact, he continued, "it seems the only people against the Brady bill are psychopaths, criminals, drug dealers and the gun lobby".

"Can we beat the gun lobby?" Brady then asked. His answer: "Yes."

He was wrong. Last October the Brady bill was bottled up in the House and never reached the floor.

Undeterred, the Bradys said they would try again when the new Congress convened on January 3. Their overriding goal is passage of the Federal bill which is now due to be considered by Congress this month. Even with its passage - and Ronald Reagan's statement of support last week makes this look increasingly likely - the Bradys and other gun control advocates say there is much else to be done: educating people about handgun violence and safety, implementing efficient and through background checks, finding ways to curb traffic in handguns among private owners and making sure that gun laws, once in place, stay in place.

"The gun lobby never gives up," Sarah Brady says. "You get a good law and they do everything they can to undo it."

The Bradys lobby, speak, write letters, take part in radio and television commercials, monitor politicians' positions on gun issues, keep a close eye on the National Rifle Association and its allies in Congress. Late last year Sarah Brady stole a march on the NRA with her effective involvement in political campaigns. All of this, of course, is standard operating procedure for active members of public-interest pressure groups, but with a difference: the Bradys are living symbols of what can happen to lives if lawmakers refuse to listen.

DESPITE the paralysis that affects much of his body, and the fatigue and the terrible pain (and the phenobarbital that he takes to control seizures), Jim Brady is still the irrepressible fellow who was nearly dismissed from his job as Reagan's campaign press secretary. That was in 1980, when he was in a plane full of reporters shortly after President Reagan made his curious observation in Ohio that trees cause more pollution than cars and factories. Brady peered out the window, pointed out a forest fire and shouted: "Killer trees | Killer trees |"

He looks better in person than still photos, probably because of his good humour and vitality. But his right eye droops, there is that angry scar across his forehead and most days he cannot walk more than a few steps at a time. To watch him, hear him, get in or out of a car or in and out of his wheelchair is to comprehend only slightly what this man goes through. He moans and curses and stifles outright screams. "Oh, oh, God, oh, god-damn, oh, ohhh, ohhHHHHHH....." He calls his physical therapists "physical terrorists".

Sarah Brady is relentlessly cheerful. When she is with her husband, she seems neither to lead nor to follow, although she is something of the senior partner by virtue of health and mobility. Rather, she is there. "Gradually things shifted to where Sarah was basically in control," says Mollie Dickenson, who wrote a book about the Bradys, Thumbs Up, which is being turned into a Home Box Office movie starring Beau Bridges as Jim and Joan Allen as Sarah. "Jim has adjusted to his limits."

The Bradys, in fact, have one of those rare partnerships in which each is finely tuned to the other. They are independent but they function like two people sawing wood. They do not always travel or appear together. He travels as vice-chairman of the National Organisation on Disability; as chairman of Handgun Control, she is often somewhere else supporting gun control legislation.

HANDGUN Control's advertisements point out that people in the United States seem to murder each other with stunning regularity (see table). Given the staggering number of guns out there the organisation concedes the certainty of some of them falling into the hands of criminals. "But we do know that most guns used in crimes are new guns," Sarah Brady says, "and we can do something about that."

Ask Jim Brady.

"I'm not here to sell wheelchairs," he told a television reporter in Orlando who wanted to know what his motives were. "If anything, I'm here to stop the growth of wheelchairs. I know how easy it is to blow somebody away with a piece. John Hinckley knows how easy it was for him to get his handguns. Could we have stopped him? I don't know. But I know we can stop many others. I don't want to go through this again."

THE battle waged by the Bradys and Handgun Control against the NRA for the hearts and minds of America's gun-owning public, and the public in general, is a classic David and Goliath struggle.

The National Rifle Association was founded in 1871 and has about three million members and an operating budget of $86 million. Pete Shields, a native of Delaware, helped found Handgun Control Inc in 1974 after his 23-year-old son was murdered with a handgun in California. His organisation has 250,000 active members (although it has the names of a million supporters - signers of petitions, contributors and others - in its computers) and an operating budget of $6.5 million.

Given its war chest and membership, the NRA has long vied with the American Medical Association as Washington's most powerful lobby. Its tactics are blunt and direct: reward friends and punish enemies. For years it perpetuated the misconception that the Founding Fathers decreed in the Constitution that the ordinary American has a "right to keep and bear arms". Thus, emblazoned across the face of the NRA's headquarters in Washington are the words "The right of the people to keep and bear Arms shall not be infringed".

Those are, of course, the words of the Second Amendment to the Constitution. But they are artfully truncated. The Amendment says: "A well-regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms shall not be infringed." The key words are "a well-regulated Militia".

If the words of the Amendment are not clear enough, the United States Supreme Court has, over the past 114 years, ruled at least three times that the Second Amendment has not the slightest thing to do with an individual's right to bear arms ("or to arm bears, either," Jim Brady likes to say) but rather to the right of the States to raise an armed militia.

PRO-GUNS forces argue that gun controls don't really do any good. "It is the very places that have the strictest gun laws that have the most crime,"says James Jay Baker, chief lobbyist for the NRA's Institute for Legislative Action.

Baker cites places like New York and Washington, which have very strict gun laws and very high rates of violence. To bolster that claim, he points to the nation's capital as having the highest number of murders. This argument, however, ignores the fact that cities like Washington and New York are awash in illegal guns because it is a simple matter to go elsewhere to get them.

In one analysis, the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms found that 96 per cent of the guns used in crimes in New York City were purchased outside the city and almost exclusively outside the state. The same is true in Washington, where one can buy a gun just over the line in Virginia. Virginia, Florida and Georgia form the biggest source of illegal handguns in the East.

Increasingly, the public and legislators are confronted with the problem of easy access to guns in some states. In Georgia, in 1987, an Atlanta woman named Mozella Dansby, distraught at being passed over for a promotion at work, bought a gun and used it the next day to shoot two of her supervisors and then to kill herself. Atlanta has a gun-purchase waiting period, so the woman went to nearby Smyrna, which has no such law, to buy the gun.

There are other examples, and they occur frequently enough to cause more and more state legislatures to defy the once indomitable gun lobby to adopt waiting periods. In fact there is clear evidence that the power of the NRA may be waning.

Not only is there increased public awareness of the handgun problem, there has also been the defection of most major police groups, once staunch allies of the NRA. The role played by Sarah Brady and Handgun Control, and more recently by Jim Brady, has also clearly been a factor.

"She has been very effective," concedes James Baker, the NRA lobbyist, "but in large part because of her personal situation." John M. Snyder, chief lobbyist for the Citizens Committee for the Right to Keep and Bear Arms, conceding Sarah Brady's effectiveness, also maintains it is "based on emotion".

With her husband often at her side, Sarah Brady is increasingly successful at selling gun control at the state level. At the Federal level, however, after a promising beginning, there was considerable frustration last autumn as House Speaker Thomas S. Foley bottled up the Brady bill despite strong support for it. A bill to ban assault weapons did not come to a House vote after its surprise passage in the Senate.

Foley's publicly stated reason for not allowing the Brady bill to be considered as part of a pending crime bill was that time was critical and he did not want to bog the crime bill down with attachments and amendments, particularly when he felt the Brady bill was not likely to be acted on in the Senate. Nonetheless, he allowed an amendment, strongly supported by the NRA, from Jolene Unsoeld, his colleague from Washington State, also a Democrat.

While the crime bill banned the assembly of assault weapons of foreign design from imported or domestic parts, Unsoeld's amendment allowed assembly from domestic parts. The bill sailed through. The day after she introduced the amendment, Unsoeld got a campaign donation of $4,950 from the NRA's political action committee.

Unsoeld denied any deal with the NRA, as did Foley. But the public-interest group Common Cause found that of 49 representatives who received more than$10,000 each from the NRA over the past five years, 48 voted for the Unsoeld amendment, with Foley, who got $14,850, not voting.

Common Cause also found that the 257 House members who voted for the Unsoeld amendment received an average of $5,432 from the NRA's political action committee. That adds up to $1.4 million.

urn:contentItem:5578-GX51-JD34-V0PN-00000-00UNRAVELLING THE SILK ROAD1998-06-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:50ZLexisNexisMAGAZINEPg. 10UNRAVELLING THE SILK ROADTRAVELTONY GREY

In the midst of battle beyond the Eastern frontier, a shimmering wall of supernatural light flashed upon Crassus' legion, blinding its dreaded troops. Already hard pressed, the disciplined Roman ranks faltered and then broke. The famed eagle standards fell to igno-minious capture and its commander, the richest man in Rome and from whose name we derive the word "crass", was held down while his Parthian captors poured molten gold down his throat.

The Parthians, from what is now modern Iran, had acquired their secret weapon from the Chinese in exchange for an ostrich. It was silk, sewn into long banners, its smooth surface reflecting the sun. The battle of Carrhae in 53 BC was the West's introduction to the diaphanous textile that had been invented in China, probably 4,000 to 5,000 years ago. Within decades noble families of Rome were wearing it.

We flew to Xian with Edmund Capon, director of the Art Gallery of NSW, and his wife Joanna. Both are well regarded scholars of Chinese Buddhism and its peregrination along the Silk Road from India.

Xian endured eleven Chinese dynasties as the nation's capital and was the eastern starting point of the network of ancient caravan tracks which the 19th century German geographer Baron von Richthoven named the Silk Road. It is perhaps best known in the West as the site of the terracotta warriors grandiosely entombed with Qin Shihuang, the first emperor of a united China.

But it deserves greater fame. Its archaeological treasures, which could rival Egypt's when fully explored, corroborate the story of a city under the Han dynasty as powerful in the East as Rome was in the West and as glorious under the Tang as Byzantium. This was where Chinese script and Sino Communism began.

A Chinese scholar there introduced us to the popular saying: "If you wish to understand China in the last decade, go to the Shenzhen special economic zone; if you wish to understand China in the last century, go to Shanghai; but if you wish to understand China over the last 3,000 years, go to Xian."

Extraneous forces have isolated China. For centuries the ferocious Turkic tribes, known to them as the Shiong-nu and to us as the Huns, sealed its western frontiers. Further west lies the vast tectonic crunch that curbs passage into the plains of Central Asia and India. Alexander the Great reached Afghanistan but it appears that his geographical knowledge was stunted by the Pamir mountains, perceived historically as the "Roof of the World". East and West were fated to live in ignorance of each other. That was the case until a formal trade route arose to connect the two segments of the world.

In 138 BC, hearing that the Yueh chi, a Scythian tribe and traditional enemies of the Huns, had been driven west in a series of sanguinary battles and might be fostering revenge, the Han emperor Wu-ti dispatched a mission of a hundred men led by Zhang Qian to solicit an alliance.

After 13 years of perilous adventures the indomitable emissary returned - without the support of the Yueh chi, whose vengeance had drained away in their new land, but with tales of 36 fabulously rich kingdoms in the shadowy west. Best of all was intelligence of a heavenly breed of horse, more powerful than the Chinese species, which would run so hard that it sweated blood. Smelling military advantage, the emperor forwarded trade delegations to acquire the superior mounts, inaugurating a mercantile link that would internationalise the world.

For commerce to flourish peace must rule. Gradually the jingoistic Han armies subdued the fractious tribes and, despite periods of tumultuous dynastic decline, the Chinese secured the Silk Road region until Genghis Khan imposed his Pax Mongolica in the Middle Ages. Then the xenophobic Ming dynasty closed China off from the outside world, ringing down the curtain on the epic commercial drama.

The human drive to obtain what somebody else has can be expressed by theft, force or trade. While examples of the first two appear in its record, the Silk Road is arguably history's paramount case study of the latter method in pre-modern times. The earliest trade was in pigments, jade and religious articles. Later, from the East, appeared silk, furs, bronze weapons, rhubarb, porcelain from highly fired kaolin not produced in the West, and rag paper. The West exported textiles, rhinoceros horn, tortoise shells, ivory, metal, glassware and gold to finance its current account deficit.

It was a business of middlemen. Merchants would not complete the arduous journey of 14,000 km but would sell their goods at trading centres along the way. By the time the products reached their destination they had been marked up many times. In Rome, silk became so expensive that the Emperor Tiberius sought to ban its use as a plague on the economy, synchronously condemning it as an invitation to lasciviousness.

From the ancient portal of the Silk Road, now a bustling modernising city of close to four million upwardly mobile souls, we flew back in time to Kashgar, as far west as it is possible to travel before leaving China.

The old caravan town is the gathering point of the two main Silk Roads that passed north and south of the fearsome Taklamakan Desert, said to have devoured more lives than any other in the world (the name in Turkic means "enter and never return"). Marco Polo, who travelled there in the 13th century, reported on the spirit voices that lured countless travellers into the maw of the endless wastelands.

The Chinese section of the Silk Road stands chiefly in the autonomous province of Xinjiang, meaning "new frontier". Its population is predominantly Uighur, a Turkic people related to the ancient Huns who were indigenous to the region. The area, formerly called Chinese Turkistan, is the size of Alaska and is highly fertile when watered; but most of it receives only 10 mm of rainfall a year.

At the frontier airport we were met by our guide, a cheerful, plump Uighur woman. Guides are virtually the only English speakers in this remote land where Caucasians are still a curiosity. Our hotel was concrete-block basic but the local food was palatable - mutton spiced with cumin and chilli, laghman noodles and clean, fresh greens. And even though we were in a Muslim region, beer was commonly available.

Xinjiang is the cradle of the Turkic race. From it successive tribes fanned out to the north, to the Mongolian grasslands, and west, across Central Asia to eastern Europe. Attila the Hun could trace his ancestry to this part of the world, as can the inhabitants of Turkey today. The Mongols are closely related.

Kashgar is full of archetypal Turkic buildings: intricately carved wooden balconies overhang the street, leaning on finely chiselled posts.

The Sunday bazaar is reputedly the largest open-air market in the world. More than a hundred thousand people saunter through on the day, as they have done since the heyday of the Silk Road when Kashgar was called its pearl. We were time-warped back into the Middle Ages; only the outdoor television sets blaring out the din of action movies disclosed our generation. The donkey is the engine of choice - at rush hour donkey carts, not cars, jam the roads.

Products were grouped as in a sprawling department store. Sound and smell marked the boundaries, tinkers beating their pots and pans like Caribbean steel drums, slumped sacks of colourful spices perfuming the air. High-cheekboned men being shaved bald sat under red, yellow and navy umbrellas. Few women ventured into the main part of the market. A cluster of about 500, most of them dressed in the brown shawls of Islamic fundamentalism, loitered down by the muddy river chatting; none was engaged in commerce.

Cooked food - barbecued satay sticks and oven-baked bread - dominated the bazaar. Sheep heads bubbled in murky water. Suddenly a swarthy cook would pull one of them out and hack it in half with an axe. Eager customers in traditional garb would demolish steaming eyes, brains and cheeks. Large curved lumps of yellow meat - smoked sheep lungs - quivered as bite-sized chunks were sliced off.

A circle of men squatted around a contingent of fighting cocks for sale; the shoulders and thighs of the birds were pecked bare from participation in a sport which is banned in most parts of the world.

Xinjiang still lives with the charms of the past. In the small oasis of Toyuk on the Silk Road we were the first Europeans to have been seen since 1989. But life is changing for the indigenous Turkic people, who look to Central Asia for their roots, not to the Middle Kingdom that has incorporated them.

In local affairs Xinjiang retains autonomy, but in matters of national importance China has the say. Racial tension stalks the land that the Uighurs traditionally own. In 1990 local anger at birth control restrictions quickly turned into anti-Han demonstrations. Three years later in Kashgar, a fatal explosion in a building signalled frustration with Chinese dominance. The authorities clamped down fiercely and a reduction in civil liberties followed. Now, Peoples' Liberation Army stations bestride every large town.

Nevertheless, the races get along on a functional level and, in the absence of a specific grievance exploding in the presence of laxness by the authorities, there seems little danger of widespread rebellion. Economic growth, escorted by an abundance of food, is calming the savage breast.

Religion remains a problem for China in this region to which merchants travelling along the Silk Road brought Islam in the Middle Ages. Banned during the Cultural Revolution, attendance at mosques is now permitted. Ayatollah Khomeini visited Kashgar and prayed ostentatiously in the 15th century Aidka mosque, the largest in China.

Still, official policy disapproves. Children under 18 are denied religious education and only two madressas (religious schools) struggle to serve the needs of several million faithful. The people are not especially pious, being more aligned to Central Asian moderation than Iranian theocracy, but they are deeply attached to the social dictates of Islam.

Just outside Kashgar we stopped at the old British Consulate, Chini Bagh. The grand piece of Victoriana has faded with the glories of Empire, declining into an unkempt restaurant hugged by a few neglected rose bushes struggling with weeds.

Nearby, bales and crates were being packed in a courtyard and loaded onto trucks. In rudimentary English, the Pakistani boss told us he buys cheap Chinese sewing machine parts, dinner sets, calculators and clothing and hauls them from Kashgar in a four-day trek over the Karakorum mountains to Peshawar, where he keeps a shop. The products are different and the camels have gone, but the Silk Road still operates comme il faut.

From Kashgar we started our journey east along the Silk Road, north of the Taklamakan Desert, and within a few hundred metres of the Heavenly Mountains (called Tianshan in Chinese) stretching to Urumqi 1,500 km away. Glacial melt flows down from these celestial bodies to the desert, creating sporadic oases along the way. But since the last Ice Age, the capriciousness of the water courses, which mysteriously appear and disappear, has depopulated dozens of once-thriving cities and left them lost under a mask of sand. Archaeologists salivate over the thought of the ancient treasures that may be hidden out there.

On our left stood the endless wall of the Heavenly Mountains, with its red haematite layering, white salt patches and green chlorite intrusions splashed on the beige landscape like a giant abstract mural. Textural patterns alter as run-off intensifies, from wrinkles at the top to deeply etched drainage channels lower down the slopes.

It was hard to imagine water as one looked at the dry, brown camel thorn that littered the grey stony soil as far as the eye could see. Trucks half a kilometre apart thundered past our minibus in the 30 degree heat, their drivers struggling against lassitude on the straight, featureless road. Some of them succumbed: we saw the aftermath of horrific collisions - burnt out behemoths clutching each other in the ditch, twisted into macabre sculptures of death.

Willy-willies like puffs of smoke warned us that the baleful Taklamakan dust storms appear as suddenly as did the devastating hordes of Genghis Khan 800 years ago. We were caught in one, fortunately mild, in which visibility nevertheless plunged to snow blizzard level.

A few metres off the road lies the oasis valley of Kizil, where some of the most important Buddhist caves in Xinjiang slumber through the modern era. There the mountains begin to take on a surreal quality in the dust haze, flat-grey against a two-dimensional horizon, and jagged like ripped paper. Sometimes at their base, erosion patterns form the shape of Scythian caps.

The great religions of the ancient world were the main intellectual cargo of the Silk Road. Persian Manichaeism, Nestorian Christianity and Buddhism all travelled east to China. But Buddhism, founded in the 6th century BC and adopted by Emperor Ashoka of India as the State religion three centuries later, was the most influential.

Trade flowed over the Karakorum mountains both west and east from North India, but the Buddhist monks who travelled with the caravans found a market for their ideas only in the East. Perhaps it was because the prevailing thought structure there was Confucianism, which dealt with the appropriate moral structure of society rather than with a system of spiritual evolution. Even though Taoism explored a mystical connection with nature and ventured onto the metaphysical plane, essentially the spiritual field was left open. In the West it was occupied by Christianity and Islam.

In the 1st century the Han emperor Ming-ti converted to Buddhism following a vision of a flying apsara (Buddhist angel) in a dream, and established the Indian import as the official religion of China. Interest in the teachings of Prince Siddhartha, the original Buddha, erupted. Monks, missionaries and pilgrims flocked along the Silk Road, banding with the merchants in caravans for safety.

At oases along the way they carved small caves out of the friable loess rock, which they decorated with religious frescoes painted from local earth pigments. The monks used these caves as living quarters and devotional centres and the frescoes served as a teaching medium.

The caves at Kizil display some of the finest Buddhist art of the Mahayana style in Central Asia. They are 30 metres up a cliff face in a remote cul de sac. When the Muslim image defacers later rampaged along the Silk Road they missed the beautiful murals. However, many were not to survive the attentions of Albert von le Coq, the 19th century German archaeological adventurer who took camel loads of mural treasures back to Berlin on the pretext that they would be safer in a Western museum. Most were destroyed in World War II.

Others, too, tramped through the oasis towns and made off with the cultural treasures of the desert. The most famous was Sir Aurel Stein, who filched thousands of price-less Buddhist manuscripts from Dunhuang, bribing the simple monk who guarded the cache with a few pounds. He is considered the prime "Foreign Devil" by the Chinese for the work he did, ironically so revered in the West until recently. Contemporary sensitivities about the appropriation of national heritage have inhibited the museum community. At the British Museum, which houses the priceless relics, almost none of Stein's acquisitions are on display in the Central Asian collection.

The construction of the murals facilitated their removal. The artist would prepare the surface of the wall with a paste of camel dung, clay and chopped straw, over which he spread a stucco. Art plunderers merely had to cut the frescoes off in sizes that fitted camel packing cases.

The murals at Kizil, like the many others along the Silk Road, depict the mythological Buddhist tales known as the Jatarka stories. They tell of the various lives of Buddha who was reincarnated as a bear, a deer, a rabbit and other animals. The great disciple Sakyamuni, who stars on the cave walls, preached the principles of self sacrifice

through the myths. One that frequently appears is of the stag who lay across a river during a forest fire, acting as a bridge for escaping animals. Though injured by the trampling, the stag held on until the last animal, a crippled rabbit, crossed over. It then died of exhaustion. Each story takes five minutes to tell but is encapsulated in a 40 centimetre lozenge.

Every cave makes a particular artistic statement. A garuda eats a snake as he guards the Buddha sitting on the purifying lotus; Prince Siddhartha rides to heaven on his white horse; flying apsaras playing the lute depict the ethereal nature of the faith; mountains painted like closely held fingers reach to paradise; and Bodhisattvas - followers of Buddha who help others to attain salvation - pray for enlightenment.

The earliest paintings, dating from the 3rd century, were done in the Gandhara style, from what is now Afghanistan and the Peshawar valley. Influenced by Greek culture brought to that region by Alexander the Great, the style incorporates Hellenistic features. The vogue changed as Chinese ascendancy grew; the faces became more oriental. By the 7th century, blue and turquoise pigments announced the arrival of the efflorescent Tang dynasty.

Small figures at the bottom of many of the cave paintings, placed discreetly underneath the celestial beings, are reminders of the symbiosis of art and commerce. In exchange for donations, wealthy merchants were immortalised on the walls.

The scenery along the Silk Road is majestic, particularly the section leading to Kucha, one of the primary Buddhist centres in Xinjiang. The bumpy asphalt road cuts through the foothills of the Tienshan, which spread like waves on an angry sea, then debouch onto an immense grass plateau where a herd of near-to-extinction Bactrian camels was grazing. In the panoramic landscape a 1st century Han beacon tower still stands, its warning fire now extinguished.

Outside Kucha stands the 3rd century BC Jaoguli temple. The Chinese monk Xuan Zhang stayed there on his pilgrimage to India through 36 kingdoms, which he undertook in order to bring back an unadulterated version of the Buddhist sutras. His feat delivered an intellectual base that enriched the theologically skimpy folk tales that had marked the launch of the religion into China.

The Chinese language with its concrete structure does not easily accommodate the subtleties and abstractions of the Indian mind. Xuan Zhang's translations apparently came closest to the essence of the Buddhist revelations. They lit a conflagration of interest in Buddhism throughout China and are now preserved in the specially constructed Wild Goose pagoda in Xian.

Each oasis town along the Silk Road is famous for a fruit. The apricot denotes Kucha. Our guide led us to one of the lush orchards that girdle the built-up area. An elderly farmer assailed the branches of his apricot-laden trees, showering us with ripe fruit, then invited us to take tea. The inside of his cool mud-brick house was heaped with oasis produce - peaches, walnuts, miniature dates that tasted like citrus and more apricots.

The principal reason China took such pains to incorporate Xinjiang, fretting over the possibility that the Uighurs might go the independent way of their ex-Soviet brethren on the other side of the Pamirs, are the prodigious resources of iron ore, coal, gold, silver, antimony, copper and petroleum in the region. The oil discovered in the Taklamakan in 1987, estimated by Chinese geologists to consist of 74 billion barrels (three times the reserves of the US), augurs petroleum autarchy for China.

Xinjiang sits in the midst of titanic plate collisions between Eurasia and Indo-Africa. These have created some of the richest and most extensive mineral deposits in the world. It is an exploration geologist's dream.

We passed through Korla, the dormitory of the 50,000 oil exploration workers who have invaded the Tarim Depression, 800 km north-west of Lop Nor, the Chinese nuclear weapons testing site. Exxon, Total, Agip and other foreign companies have entered into joint ventures called "risk investments" that entitle them to explore and develop for five years.

Oil wealth at the crass level is beginning to seep into the Silk Road at Korla and no doubt will spread its cultural monotony throughout the region. We felt fortunate to have travelled there while it was still unspoiled.

From the high country we descended through the Empty Valley pass into a vast depression at the bottom of which lies Turpan, famous for its grapes. One hundred and fifty-four metres below sea level, it is the lowest town on earth. The heat in full summer - temperatures reach more than 50C - would surprise even Australians enured to the Pilbara at Marble Bar. It was 43C while we were there, the heat relieved somewhat by the grape vine arbours that covered the main road.

Since the Han times 2,000 years ago, the local people have obtained their water from a 5,000 square kilometre system of wells, called Karez, dug in rows and connected by underground channels. The water rolls down from the Tianshan Mountains and is reticulated out of the reach of the desiccating sun. No-one remembers who installed the system, but the most reliable opinion is that the Persians brought their technology east along the Silk Road.

The Turpan Basin is considered particularly salubrious and is famous for the longevity of its people, attributed by the locals to the near-zero humidity and a diet consisting primarily of raisins and dried apricots. Arthritis sufferers traditionally have trekked there for treatment. The affected parts of the body are buried in the burning sand and, if the patients can withstand the temperature, the pain disappears.

Just outside Turpan the ancient oasis city of Gaochang dozes in front of the Flaming Mountains, whose jagged structure leaps out of the desert like a monstrous fire. Deep vertical crevasses engraved into the reddish rock catch the sunlight, inspiring the local myth that it was formed out of the mortal struggle between the archetypal hero, Karahoja, and a fire-breathing dragon.

Gaochang, built of mud-brick and rammed earth and now slouching into the desert, was a centre of Buddhism, Nestorian Christianity and Manichaeism, a Persian offshoot of Zoroastrianism founded in 300 AD whose adherents fled east to escape persecution as heretics.

The ruins of a temple destroyed in the Cultural Revolution display the ancient arch structure known as the barrel vault. The locals still employ the style. Better preserved is the old fortress city of Jiaohe, whose weathered mud-brick buildings look like primeval sculptures placed at random on the burning plateau. Shapes and shadows rise up in solitude to an Australia-blue sky, silent messengers of the past.

The story of the ancient Silk Road is rich in evidence of the way ideas inevitably follow commerce. Besides religion, other ideas migrated along the venerable axis. The know-how to make silk, porcelain, gunpowder, the clock, the compass, printing and rag paper seeped into the West from China along the Silk Road, and much ventured the other way also. Glass, invented by the Romans, was prized more than gold in China.

Today we have new ways to convey ideas, and indeed all forms of information. But like the old Silk Road, they often involve a network of business dealings and are motivated by the desire to facilitate economic activity. We sensed part of that process, in its most romantic form, out there in the wilds of Xinjiang.

urn:contentItem:4P7G-YG80-TXN5-R1PV-00000-00DEATH, INTRIGUE IN WORLD OF SKYDIVING1988-10-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:50ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 4DEATH, INTRIGUE IN WORLD OF SKYDIVINGSUNDAY SPOTLIGHTWENDY BACON

"EDWARDS you're dead" and "JE Die". These are crudely drawn signs which appeared in the vicinity of the Campbelltown home of Mr John Edwards.

There have been other ugly incidents: rocks thrown at his house, wheel nuts loosened on his car, plus telephone threats.

These have been part of life for Mr Edwards and his family during the past year. These, and unemployment.

Yet, less than 18 months ago, Mr Edwards believed he had made it in the exciting and elite world of parachuting.

After experiencing the thrills of jumping, he had chosen a job as a maker of parachutes at the Sydney firm, Parachutes Australia.

He had been recommended by his previous employer, the National Safety Council of Australia (Vic Division), one of the biggest users of parachutes in Australia.

At weekends, he worked casually at the Wilton parachuting school in Sydney's west, one of the biggest in the southern hemisphere.

But last year, he fell foul of those who run Australian parachuting. He was sacked by Parachutes Australia (PA) and stripped of his qualifications until 1992 by the Australian Parachute Federation, the body authorised by aviation authorities to run the parachuting industry.

This effectively means Mr Edwards has no immediate prospects of parachute work.

His downfall can be traced to two parachute tragedies at Wilton.

On May 10 last year, Lorna Rowse, a student on her first jump, leapt from the plane. She froze, her parachute failed to open, and she fell to her death

MR Edwards began packing parachutes at Wilton the following weekend. To his surprise, his workmate in this skilled job was an unqualified 16-year-old.

Next, Mr Edwards spread a parachute and there, in his own handwriting, was the word "UNSERVICEABLE".

He had tested the parachute and discarded it as unsafe at his previous job at the Sale headquarters of the National Safety Council.

It was one of a batch of secondhand parachutes acquired by Mr Graeme Hill, the head of the Wilton Parachute School.

A powerful figure in the parachute world, Mr Hill is also a Parachute Federation official, has trained army parachutists around the world, and has worked as a consultant to the Safety Council.

Mr Edwards later told a NSW coroner that when he approached Mr Hill about the unserviceable parachutes, he was told: "It's OK, all is fine," a conversation which Mr Hill could not recall at the inquest into the death of Lorna Rowse and another parachutist.

Not satisfied, Mr Edwards complained to Parachute Federation director of rigging Mr Dave Smith.

This was not difficult because Mr Smith was also his boss at Parachutes Australia. Mr Smith also works as a consultant to the Safety Council and aviation authorities.

According to Mr Edwards, Mr Smith said: "Don't worry about it, we'll sort it out."

Mr Smith later told the coroner's court he did not regard this as a complaint to him as director of rigging and, in any case, regarded the parachutes as safe.

By chance, Mr Edwards did not work at Wilton the following weekend when more novices jumped. Among the parachutists were the Allison brothers and their friend Mick Hickey.

As that Sunday passed, Mr Maxwell Allison waited anxiously for his three sons and Hickey to jump. As he later told the coroner: "I was concerned it was becoming too dark and unsafe."

He believed "the training had been too rushed and the students were tired and anxious after a long day".

His three sons were safely on the ground when a confident Mick Hickey jumped. The lines on his parachute twisted and it failed to open properly. Before his reserve parachute could open, he was dead on the ground.

Mr Edwards was appalled when he learned of Hickey's death. He was worried more students would die if nothing was done about safety at Wilton. When a Channel Seven news team approached him, he decided to talk.

Parachute instructor Mr Graham Carney, who had worked at Wilton, was also interviewed by Channel 7. Mr Carney later told the coroner: "I was asked to get students out of the aircraft as quickly as possible and told not to debrief at all..."

Mr Edwards was at work at PA when his comments were previewed on 2GB. Immediately afterwards, he was sacked. "When I asked why I was being sacked they told me I may become an embarrassment to them," he said.

THAT night, his telephone rang every 15 minutes until 2am. Some times threats were made.

(This year, Dave Smith's son, Paul, signed an agreement promising not to harass John Edwards and his family.)

Mr Edwards' problems were just beginning. Soon afterwards, he and Mr Carney were charged with "failing to act in the best interests of the Australian Parachutes Federation by making public statements harmful to the sport".

Officials of the Parachute Federation, Mr Smith of Parachutes Australia, and Mr Hill, of Wilton Parachute School, were present throughout the Parachute hearing which voted to suspend the two men for three years after which the decision would be reviewed.

In practice, they could no longer work in the industry.

Police investigator Detective Phil Baldwin later subpoenaed a tape-recording of this "trial" for the coroner's court investigating the two deaths.

In his report, he described the proceedings as being conducted in a "most immature and unprofessional fashion".

To make matters even worse for Mr Carney and Mr Edwards, the Department of Aviation investigated their complaints about safety and found them baseless.

But coroner Maurice Hodgson reached a different conclusion. His main task was to investigate the cause of the deaths but he also examined other evidence about safety. The coroner was most impressed by Army Parachute School instructor Mr David Christie, who found "the material reviewed left me with the impression that decisions on operating practices (at Wilton) were based as much on financial rewards as they are on safety considerations".

Two former students gave evidence they had seen a hesitant novice pushed from the aircraft. Despite a denial from the instructor, Mr Christie said the allegations should be investigated.

Mr Hill told the coroner that the second-hand parachutes which had been acquired from the National Safety Council had been tested and fixed but did not know in what way.

The coroner found as Edwards had alleged: that students did jump close to last light; an unqualified parachutist packed for live jumps; and Safety Council parachutes marked "unserviceable" were purchased by Wilton.

In suggesting a public inquiry into parachute training, he recommended that no body with a vested interest in parachuting be involved. Detective Baldwin explicitly recommended the Parachute Federation not be involved.

Parachute Federation executive director Mr Harvey Ritchie, who worked for the Department of Aviation for 14 years, described an inquiry as a waste of public money.

"We're a little bit upset about the final results of the coronial inquiry,"he said. "It implies the Federal Government department responsible for aviation safety doesn't know what it is doing."

The Federal Government has not yet decided whether to hold an inquiry.

NATIONAL Safety Council public relations manager Mr Bruce Savage agrees that the coroner's finding that the council supplied "unserviceable"parachutes is bad for the image of a body which boasts the most sophisticated safety services in the country.

The Victorian division of the Safety Council is part of an Australia-wide, loose federation of State Safety Councils.

While many people think it is a government body, it is in fact a private company. Set up in 1927 with a charter to promote safety standards, in the 1980s, it suddenly blossomed into a hi-tech sophisticated safety service with bases sprinkled around the continent. The Victorian division dwarfs all other state bodies.

Mr Savage says the council did not attend the inquest because it did not wish to get involved in a bunfight "which it could not win".

Instead, it relied on Parachute Federation and aviation authority findings that Edwards' allegations were unwarranted.

For the moment, the council is not selling the "unserviceable" parachutes.

This is not the first dispute between Mr Edwards and the council. Mr Edwards resigned from the council after management failed to resolve his complaints about other safety matters.

But despite the falling out, the council arranged for Mr Edwards to obtain a job at its parachute supplier, Parachutes Australia.

Some months after he moved to PA, an incident demonstrated to him the close relationship between PA and the council.

One morning PA boss Mr Dave Smith told him he would receive a cheque from the council. Mr Edwards was surprised because the council had paid everything they owed him, including about $1,500 moving expenses.

Later, Mr Smith gave him a cheque drawn on a Smith and Basworth account (a partnership account with his wife) for $6,594. When Mr Edwards asked what the cheque was for, he alleges Mr Smith said: "To keep everything nice and quiet.

Mr Smith denies making this comment. According to him, the money was for removal expenses. He cannot remember why the council paid the money through his account.

BACK in 1987, Mr Smith had more on his mind than parachute safety.

The company already had military contacts. It had developed and sold parachutes to the Australian special forces, the Special Air Services (SAS), for invading hostile territory.

Now, PA was expanding beyond parachute manufacturing into the role of international middleman.

The plans were ambitious: a letter to the Fiji military forces offered 6,000 Assault rifles and 5,000 Beretta handguns; a letter from the Texas Air Corporation about Continental 727s which PA wanted for a client in Venezuela; requests from the company's South American agent who wanted aircraft parts and explosives for the Peruvian air force - all were processed through the PA's small factory.

An important partner in these daring proposals was Pedro Coluzzi, a private arms and aircraft dealer from Lima, Peru. He arrived at PA's invitation last September with a huge list of parts required for the Peruvian air force.

PA introduced him to the Federal Government's Department of Administrative Services.

Negotiations began for the sale of Canberra bomber spares to PA, who through Pedro Coluzzi's firm PCB would sell them to the Peruvian Air Force.

It was an expensive way of supplying the impoverished Peruvian Government with aircraft parts.

A spokesman for the Peruvian Ambassador in Australia said he would expect his Government to deal directly with the Australian Government. The embassy was not notified of Coluzzi's presence in Australia and, despite inquiries, has received no information about the deal from Peru.

Back in the United States, Mr Coluzzi faxed PA's then manager Mr Eddie Crowther: "You already know on which bank the Air Attache has the P.A.F. (Peruvian Air Force) account."

He referred to a General Pizarro. "This guy is on our side so we cannot miss this opportunity ... we're going to make a good profit on this but more in the future if we make it."

Before the deal was completed, a report appeared in the Times on Sunday about the PA's weapons offer to Fiji.

When approached by the Times on Sunday, Mr Smith admitted the company investigated the availability of weapons, but the deal had gone no further.

Neither Mr Smith nor Mr Crowther would name the company willing to supply the weapons.

After the Times on Sunday report, Mr Smith was concerned about its effect on his Peruvian deal. According to Administrative Services officer Mr Peter Thoet: "Smith talked to us and said it was done by an employee of the firm without his knowledge. He went to great pains to deny involvement."

The Government accepted Mr Smith's word and, without investigation, completed the bomber spares deal with PA. Mr Thoet said he was satisfied the parts did reach Peru.

MR EDWARDS was sorry to leave the National Safety Council. For anyone with a sense of adventure, there could be no better place to work.

Among other things, the council fights fires, trains dogs to jump in parachutes, performs underwater rescues and provides safety services to Australian/US joint defence exercises.

There was plenty of opportunities to practise the expensive sport of parachuting.

Not long before Mr Edwards resigned, he spent a month in luxury at the Alice Springs Sheraton Hotel with Mr Friedrich and a team of council parachutists.

A plane, a bus, and an expert imported from the United States were transported to Central Australia. The reason for this exercise - not safety, but training of a parachute sports team.

All of this was his to enjoy, he believed, on one condition: "Do what you're told and don't ask too many questions."

One thing he didn't ask questions about was the military-style parachute rigs he packed but never saw used at the council.

Most council parachutes were for safety work. They have suitably bright yellow canopies and rigs with reflectors.

But PA also manufactured HALO parachutes for the council. HALO parachutes are designed for high altitude, low-opening, secret landings. They have black rigs and oxygen masks.

Council executive officer Mr John Friedrich has no knowledge of these rigs, but past employees of PA remember packing the rigs for the council.

The purpose of these rigs is only one of the enigmas of the council. Another puzzle is - from where does its money come?

Its growth has been extraordinary. According to its own figures, in 1984, expenditure and income was $11 million.

In two years, it grew to $30 million. In another two years to 1988, it more than doubled both its expenditure and income to reach $69 million. All income is from fees for service.

In the past two years, its employees doubled from 200 to 400. A number of these are defence recruits who, according to Mr Savage, see the council as a"convenient halfway house."

It has achieved all this while providing services which others cannot offer because they would make a loss.

In seven years, it has financed a fleet of 32 aircraft worth $40 million. This is less than half of the total equipment purchased or leased during this period.

While its services are used by fire, police and defence departments and some large private organisations like Esso and the Victorian State Electricity Commission, amounts paid by these bodies cannot explain its growth.

Some of its services, such as medicine for divers and its new overseas fire-fighting business actually make a loss.

The main growth, Mr Friedrich claims, comes from providing emergency services to confidential industrial clients.

According to a council chart, these industrial services raised 17 per cent of $30 million in 1986. When Mr Friedrich was asked to provide a figure for industrial services in 1988, he was not able to do so, but said it was a "bit more" than in 1986. The mystery continues.

Several years ago the council set up Safeair, a private company to handle its overseas operations, which include fire fighting in Canada, advising the Oman regime at the mouth of the Persian Gulf on underwater medicine and the Brunei armed forces on search and rescue.

IN theory, Safeair's annual accounts should be registered with the Victorian Corporate Affairs Commission but, according to a recent check, no accounts have been registered since 1985.

Not even the Tax Department has any detailed knowledge of the council's finances.

Under its charter, the council is a service for promoting safety. As a"charitable or public educational" organisation it has sales and income tax exemption.

It is its tax-free status which angers aviation rivals who compete for firefighting and search and rescue work.

One critic is SkyWest director Mr Bill Meake. "I don't think their tax-free status was designed around the activities they now perform," he said. "They were set up to promote community safety.

"Take their air ambulance service. It's purely a commercial contract to perform a service for the government which any aviation tax-paying company could perform.

"They provide services which the rest of the industry is not interested in because they are not viable. You can't have substantial sums caught up in aircraft standing idle unless you have guaranteed funding."

But the council denies it has any hidden backer. In response to such criticism, Mr Friedrich promised in 1986 to restrict the council to "aviation services for emergency and public safety requirements".

However, in 1987, Safeair agreed to takeover Mayne Bristow helicopters which provided a ferry service to the North West Shelf gas project.

When SkyWest's Mr Meake objected, council chairman Mr Max Eise explained the deal was "for investment purposes". Bristow pulled out of the deal.

As far as Mr Friedrich is now concerned the council's tax-free status places no limits on its activities. The possibilities are endless. He would like, for example, to turn the council's travel requirements to advantage by setting up a travel business.

Why not show the figures and end the speculation? "That would only add to the speculation," answers Mr Friedrich.

Instead, council officers prefer humour. They introduce the subject of the CIA. "We're not funded by the CIA, but by ASIO," quips Mr Savage.

Mr Friedrich, on the other hand, jokingly says he would love to be a CIA outfit because then "no-one would expect to see his accounts".

The CIA speculation is fuelled by the story of Intermountain, a fully-owned CIA airline which operated a forest fire-fighting service as a cover for training parachutists to drop into rough country in "dirty wars".

Gossip began when the Australian Federal Police invited the council to provide a helicopter service for demonstrations at the US base at Pine Gap.

Later there were complaints alleging helicopters had flown low over the camp and shone lights on tents.

With hindsight, council general manager Colin Gomm wishes they had not provided the Pine Gap service because of the CIA "stigma".

Another possible explanation for the council's good fortune is its links to the Australian defence forces.

The council is a beneficiary of defence privatisation moves. In recent years, it has been providing our forces with underwater rescue training and search and rescue services.

As Mr Savage puts it: "The taxpayer can no longer afford these services. We are in the position to be able to provide them."

It will receive more than $900,000 for providing search and rescue facilities for the Australian and US Air Force exercise "Operation Pitchblack"and other exercises in the Darwin area this year. To earn this, it only had to compete in a restricted tender.

According to the Minister for Defence, Mr Kim Beazley, this was due "to the short time frame to set them (the exercises) up."

Both Mr Savage and Mr Friedrich deny the council provides services to the SAS, but according to Mr Beazley it does provide the SAS with underwater training.

Mr Beazley, on the other hand, says the council has only provided the Navy with $7,350 worth of dunker (underwater rescue) training. The Sun-Herald has, however, seen documents which show the council also provides the Navy with medical services during diving exercises.

Officially, no arrangements guarantee these defence contracts. But behind the scenes the council is being encouraged to equip itself to fulfill the defence-related tasks.

The same documents show the Navy this year promised to buy $200,000 worth of services a year, if the council buys a "submersible" (underwater craft)which will be available during submarine exercises.

GOVERNMENT officials are well aware of the sensitivity of these defence relationships. In December 1986 council students on a survival course set fire to Deal Island, a Commonwealth reserve.

When most of the island's grassland was burnt, the media became interested

Reports to the then Minister for Transport, Peter Morris, noted concern by his department that journalists would "try and embrace their (the council's)involvement with the Department of Defence, in particular the SAS".

But however cosy the relationship, it does not explain the $69 million income. Official figures show the council will only receive $4,378,703 for its defence contracts from 1987 to 1989. Even allowing for omissions, the real figure cannot be much more.

The cash flow enigma remains. The only acknowledgement of possible difficulty comes from manager Mr Colin Gomm.

He agrees income only just exceeds annual expenditure. "There is no financial safety net," he said. "If users stop using our services, we go down the gurgler."

Should a body which is publicly unaccountable be encouraged to develop a monopoly in safety services for submarine, Air Force exercises and search and rescue?

What if there were no bushfires next season, or some of those private clients decided to go elsewhere for their industrial emergency services? How would the council fund those loss-making defence and other public safety activities?

urn:contentItem:6FGF-BPR3-RSNS-N0S5-00000-00Wildlife carers' burn-off fears2025-04-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:50ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Wildlife carers' burn-off fearsIan Royall

Wildlife carers fear a large burn-off planned in the state's east will harm native animal populations still recovering from the Black Summer fires five years ago.

A burn-off is scheduled this week for 2660ha in the Nicholson River valley, north of Bairnsdale in Gippsland.

But wildlife rescuers say that injured koalas and kangaroos that were saved and rehabilitated back into bushland now face a new threat from the blaze.

And it comes after another Forest Fire Management burn-off in a neighbouring valley burnt out of control last month.

Susie Pulis, from the Waterholes Wildlife Sanctuary just south of the fire zone, called for a pause and a review of the burn-off.

"We need to look after the wildlife that's there. I don't feel safe and I certainly don't trust them to burn safely." Ms Pulis said wildlife populations were still recovering.

"We went through the fires five years ago and now we see this - it's really worrying.

"I hope this doesn't get out of control. "The habitat is extremely young - five years only of growth."

Timothy Cox

Communities northeast of Ballarat have been warned to stay cautious as a bushfire continues to burn at Creswick.

Emergency services issued an advice message at midday on Friday for Cabbage Tree, Chapel Flat, Clarkes Hill, Dean, Glen Park, Springmount, and Wattle Flat.

While the blaze on Melbourne Rd, which broke out on Monday afternoon, is under control, "low level fire activity" continues within containment lines.

About 200h have been burnt, with smoke visible and 15 firefighters working at the scene.

All roads remain open, though 40km/h limits have been imposed on parts of Creswick-Dean Rd and Melbourne Rd.

On Monday, more than 50 Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA units rushed to the scene, where 300 firefighters worked alongside by five water aircraft and three large air tankers.

Further west, a bushfire at the Grampians remains out of control, with neighbouring communities warned to stay on high alert.

More than 7600h burnt by that fire, which emergency services said could burn for weeks.

Victorian property owners will be slugged with a doubling of the fire services levy rate as the government uses it to help pay other emergency services.

Motorists are also being stung with a rise in the congestion levy, which applies to parking fees, and its use will be expanded to inner-eastern suburbs.

The tax hikes come as a budget update shows Victoria's deficit has grown by $1.4 billion for this financial year. Despite this, the Allan government maintains it will record an operating surplus the year after, even though it has to spend more money on the Metro Tunnel and the state's hospitals.

The fire services levy will be renamed the emergency services and volunteers fund [ESVF] and retooled to provide money towards the State Emergency Service, Triple Zero Victoria, the State Control Centre, Forest Fire Management Victoria and Emergency Recovery Victoria.

urn:contentItem:6DC0-CNH1-F0J6-J176-00000-00Crews battle Spring Gully scrub blaze five days out from fire danger period2024-11-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:50ZLexisNexisCrews battle Spring Gully scrub blaze five days out from fire danger periodGeorgina Sebar

Seven CFA tankers were called out to battle a scrub fire on the edge of Bendigo in a timely reminder of the upcoming threat of bushfire season.

It comes after the CFA directed a warning about the dry conditions in the Bendigo area and issued a Total Fire Ban in the Mallee region as the temperature soared above 30 degrees.

Emergency crews from Golden Square (two vehicles), Maiden Gully, Bendigo, Eaglehawk, Kangaroo Flat and Fortuna responded to a slow-spreading grass fire in Bendigo Regional Park on Wednesday, November 6, 2024.

The blaze took hold along Faugh-A-Ballagh Rd in Spring Gully at 12.18pm.

No houses threatened The fire spread to around 0.3 hectares in size but was deemed under control by 12.37pm and safe at 1.17pm.

No nearby houses were affected and control of the scene has been handed over to Forest Fire Management Victoria.

Greater Bendigo's official Fire Danger Period begins on Monday, November 11.

urn:contentItem:6CJT-K5R1-JD34-V192-00000-00Maitland man joins wildfire fight effort2024-07-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:50ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Maitland man joins wildfire fight effort

Maitland fire specialist Daniel Macaree is part of a NSW deployment of firefighters sent to Canada on the weekend to help authorities battle more than 400 out of control wildfires.

About 1.5 million hectares of land has been burnt as Canada deals with 650 active fires across the country.

Mr Macree is one of four Forestry Corporation firefighters who are part of a 31 member deployment from NSW which flew out of Australia on Saturday after a request from Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre.

The NSW contingent is coordinated by the NSW Rural Fire Service and made up of 20 RFS representatives, five from National Parks and Wildlife, two from State Emergency Services and four from Forestry Corporation.

Mr Macaree will deploy as a heavy plant supervisor dozer boss. "With the current fire situation in Canada I'm expecting it to be quite challenging. I imagine I will be working with contractors most days looking for and constructing containment lines and providing access to areas," he said.

Thick smoke can be seen across Melbourne's western suburbs on Thursday afternoon as a planned burn off continues in Ravenhall.

The heavy smoke is visible from suburbs as far as Parkville and Moonee Ponds.

Forest Fire Management Victoria is burning 67ha of land in Ravenhall to "modify the vegetation abundance across the planned area to assist the promotion of Alluvial Plains Grassland".

Forest Fire Management Victoria's website states: "Without planned burning and other bushfire risk management works, bushfires will be bigger and harder for our firefighters to control."

Dubbo crews help battle fires Firefighters from Dubbo have been helping battle a number of blazes in the Narrabri area.

The NSW Rural Fire Service (RFS) Orana Team volunteers were helping tackle various fires, including the Duck Creek Pilliga Forest Fire, this week.

Smoke haze could be seen around Dubbo, emanating from the Duck Creek fire, located at Goona Creek Road, Pilliga East.

Orana Team district manager, Dave Milsteed, confirmed the "smoke drift" around Dubbo was travelling from the Duck Creek Pilliga Forest fire.

Forty-two RFS crews from across the region - including Dubbo and the Central Coast - were on site at the Duck Creek Pilliga Forest fire, supporting the Narrabri RFS Brigade.

Narrabri Fire Control Centre public information officer Kate Carter said there were six helicopters and planes water-bombing the fire.

Visitors to Victoria's parks and forests this long weekend are being urged to check conditions and think twice about lighting a campfire.

The Conservation Regulator, Forest Fire Management Victoria and Parks Victoria are reminding campers to act responsibly and be fire safe, as the combination of hot, dry and windy weather conditions increases fire risk significantly.

Since January 1, authorities have detected more than 170 unattended campfires in parks and forests across the state.

urn:contentItem:6BNM-Y6J1-JD34-V1BK-00000-00Warrant out for man charged over fire2024-03-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:50ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 16Warrant out for man charged over fireBen Loughran

The 36-year-old Bendigo man who has been charged with allegedly starting a fire in One Tree Hill on March 26 has failed to appear in court and a warrant has been issued for his arrest.

Jeida Francis was due to appear in the Bendigo Magistrates' Court on March 28, charged with recklessly causing a bushfire and criminal damage by fire.

However, he did not appear and did not give the court a reason for his absence.

Central Goldfields Crime Investigation Unit detectives charged the man after what they described was "an allegedly suspicious car fire in Strathfieldsaye".

Police said emergency services had responded to reports a vehicle was on fire in bushland near Pioneer Road about 2pm the day of the blaze.

No-one was injured in the fire, which burnt 0.6 hectares, according to Forest Fire Management Victoria.

Air support was called in to extinguish the fire after firefighters on the ground struggled to access the area given its geographic location.

After multiple waterbombs from the air, the fire was under control by 7.30pm on March 26.

FFMVic acknowledged the cause of the fire was a burnt-out car, which Victoria Police were investigating.

urn:contentItem:64R3-PPG1-F0J6-J08H-00000-00Crews work on forest fire2022-02-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:50ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Crews work on forest fireHayley Elg

Firefighters worked through Monday to extinguish a two-hectare fire at Glen Park that started early in the morning.

Country Fire Authority crews found the grass and scrub fire on a forest track off Glen Park Road just after 6am.

A spokesperson told The Courier it is believed the cause may have been a previous car fire, with six crews bringing the blaze under control just before 7am.

An advice message was issued to the community due to thick smoke visible from the Western Freeway, with the scene then handed to Forest Fire Management Victoria.

FFMVic incident controller, Chris Arnold, said there were 18 crew working on the contained fire in the morning.

With warm weather forecast for the week, crews "hit it really hard" throughout the day with heavy equipment and vehicles.

The fire did not threaten any infrastructure, but people were asked to avoid the area.

The cause of the fire is currently being investigated by Victoria Police.

urn:contentItem:6B84-H8D1-JD34-V0WC-00000-00Aircraft called to help douse fire near Princes Highway2024-02-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:50ZLexisNexisAircraft called to help douse fire near Princes HighwayKatrina Lovell

Aircraft were called to help douse a grass fire that burnt about three hectares on the Princes Highway near Pirron Yallock on Sunday, February 4, 2024.

The fire - which has been brought under control - started about 3.36pm when firefighters were alerted to reports of smoke on the highway.

A spokesperson for the State Control Centre said 18 Country Fire Authority units responded including tankers from Camperdown, Cobden, Corangamite and Pomborneit.

Victoria Police were called for traffic control, the spokesperson said.

More than 12 Forest Fire Management Victoria units were also on scene in support.

"Crews discovered two fires close together. No assets were under threat," the spokesperson said.

"An advice warning was issued to the community.

"Aircraft were called to assist and have now been released."

The fire - near Hawks Nest Road - was deemed under control at 4:28pm.

"Crews remain on scene to black out," the spokesperson said.

urn:contentItem:6B8C-4P31-JC0X-K007-00000-00VIC:Search for missing woman in forest enters second day2024-02-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:50ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Search for missing woman in forest enters second dayMELBOURNE Feb 6

  Crews continue to search for a woman who disappeared when she went on a run during a hot weather in Victoria.


   Samantha Murphy was last seen leaving her property on Eureka Street in Ballarat East to go for a run in Canadian State Forest about 7am on Sunday.
   Her family and police hold concerns for the 51-year-old's welfare due to the hot weather, with temperatures reaching 36C in the area on the day.
   Her disappearance is out of character, police said.
   State Emergency Service crews and police have been searching the state forest behind Buninyong Golf Club since Monday.
   The ground search resumed on Tuesday with the Search and Rescue Squad bringing in the dog squad, mounted police and air units.
   Forest Fire Management Victoria and Parks Victoria personnel are also involved.
   Ms Murphy is Caucasian, about 173cm tall with a slim build and shoulder-length blonde hair.
   She was last seen wearing black half-length leggings and a maroon or brown singlet.
